revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2017}} {{more citations needed|date=July 2017}} {{Infobox video game | title = 99Vidas | image = 99 vidas.jpg | caption = Xbox One box art | developer = QuByte Interactive | publisher = QuByte Interactive | designer = Bruno Carvalho | producer = Marivaldo Cabral | composer = Rafael Langoni Smith | platforms = [[Microsoft Windows]], [[macOS]], [[Linux]], [[PlayStation 4]], [[PlayStation 3]], [[PlayStation Vita]], [[Xbox One]], [[Nintendo Switch]] | released = {{collapsible list|title=December 22, 2016|'''Microsoft Windows, macOS, Linux'''
{{Video game release|WW|December 22, 2016}}'''PlayStation 3, PlayStation 4, PlayStation Vita, Xbox One'''{{vgrelease|NA|July 18, 2017{{Cite web|url=https://blog.us.playstation.com/2017/07/14/the-drop-new-playstation-games-for-7182017/ |title=PS Blog – New Releases: Week of July 18, 2017}}}}'''Nintendo Switch'''{{Video game release|WW|November 27, 2018}}}} | genre = [[Beat 'em up]] | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] }} '''''99Vidas''''' ([[Portuguese Language|Portuguese]] for "99 Lives") is a [[side-scrolling]] [[beat 'em up]] video game developed and published by QuByte Interactive, inspired by the classics of the genre of the late 1980s and 1990s, such as ''[[Double Dragon]]'', ''[[Final Fight]]'', ''[[Golden Axe]]'', and ''[[Streets of Rage]]''. It was first released for [[Microsoft Windows]], [[macOS]], and [[Linux]] in late 2016, followed by [[PlayStation 3]], [[PlayStation 4]] and [[PlayStation Vita]] in 2017, after a successful [[crowdfunding]] campaign in 2015.{{Cite web|url=https://www.catarse.me/99vidas |title=99Vidas Crowdfunding on Catarse (Portuguese)}} A [[Nintendo Switch]] release is planned in 2018.{{cite web|url=https://gematsu.com/2018/11/99vidas-definitive-edition-for-switch-launches-november-27|title=99Vidas: Definitive Edition for Switch launches November 27|website=Gematsu|accessdate=November 13, 2018}} == Gameplay == ''99Vidas'' is a side-scrolling [[beat 'em up]] featuring six playable characters (with five more unlocked through multiple play sessions, bringing the total number of playable characters to 11), and multiple cooperative and competitive game modes, for up to four players, which can be played either locally or online. Each character has unique attributes, like speed and strength, as well as an elemental alignment (Fire, Water, Wind, Lightning, et al.), which modify their regular attacks, combos and special moves. Different from more traditional games of the genre, characters gain [[experience point]]s by defeating enemies and collecting special items which can then be used by the player to upgrade their abilities and combos, or even unlock new ones. === Game Modes === ==== Campaign ==== Playable either Online or Locally. Can be played solo or with up to four players cooperatively. Players progress through the story, fighting the enemy forces, in pursuit of the ''99Vidas''. ==== Versus ==== Playable either Online or Locally. Two to four players can play head-to-head competitive matches, until there's only one standing. ==== Survival ==== Playable either Online or Locally. Can be played solo or with up to four players cooperatively. Players face several waves of enemies, with a limited number of lives and an ever-increasing difficulty, for the top spot on the Leaderboards. == Plot == ''99Vidas'' is set in a fictional [[Anachronism|anachronic]] universe, inspired by video games and the pop culture of the 1980s and 1990s. The game begins when an artifact known as ''99Vidas'' goes missing. This artifact is believed to hold such great power it could bring darkness and chaos to our very existence, should it ever fall into the hands of those with evil intents. As the Guardians of the ''99Vidas'', granted the Power of the Elements, bound to live through the ages to protect the artifact, it is your responsibility to face the forces of evil, defeat the Evil Boss and his six henchmen, and retrieve the ''99Vidas''. == Development == The development of ''99Vidas'' started in early 2015 as a project of developer QuByte Interactive in partnership with the Gaming Podcast ''99Vidas''{{Cite web|url=http://99vidas.com.br/equipe-99vidas/ |title= Abount 99Vidas - Official Website (Portuguese)}} from Brazil.{{Cite web|url=http://br.ign.com/99-vidas/38822/news/99vidas-saiba-tudo-sobre-o-game-que-nasceu-de-um-podcast |title=IGN Brazil interviews 99Vidas Game Designer (Portuguese)}} The idea was to develop a brand new [[beat 'em up]] that would both pay tribute to the classics of the genre while also updating the gameplay with more modern elements. Prior to initiating a crowdfunding campaign the developers wanted to have something to show the backers so they could better understand the concept behind the game, so a first [[game demo|demo]] was developed using [[Unity game engine|Unity]] featuring hand-drawn sprites and sound samples to emulate the look and feel of the [[Fourth generation of video game consoles|16-bit]]. After the [[game demo|demo]] was completed, the decision to start a crowdfunding campaign{{Cite web|url=https://www.catarse.me/99vidas |title=99Vidas Crowdfunding on Catarse (Portuguese)}} was announced in July 2015.{{Cite web|url=http://99vidas.com.br/99vidas-178-99vidas-o-jogo-campanha/ |title= 99Vidas about the Crowdfunding Campaign (Portuguese)}} The initial goal was to raise R$80,000.00 [[BRL|Brazilian Real]] for the [[Steam (software)|Steam]] version of the game. The campaign went on to raise a total of R$127,309.78, enabling the development of the console versions – [[PlayStation 4]], [[PlayStation 3]], [[PlayStation Vita]], [[Xbox One]]. Simultaneous to the [[crowdfunding]] campaign the games was also submitted to the [[Steam Greenlight]] process,{{Cite web|url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?l=portuguese&id=518391940 |title= 99Vidas on Steam Greenlight}} which was cleared in less than a week{{Cite web|url=http://overloadr.com.br/noticias/2015/09/jogo-do-99vidas-e-aprovado-no-steam-greenlight/ |title= Overloadr - 99Vidas Greenlit on Steam (Portuguese)}} following approval by the Steam Community, allowing the developers to [[Self-publishing|self-publish]] the game on the [[Steam (software)|Steam digital marketplace]]. The game was then released on December 22, 2016{{Cite web|url=http://99vidas.com.br/99vidas-250-99vidas-o-jogo-lancamento/ |title= 99Vidas about the Game Release (Portuguese)}} on [[Steam (software)|Steam]] and on July 18, 2017{{Cite web|url=https://blog.us.playstation.com/2017/07/14/the-drop-new-playstation-games-for-7182017/ |title=PS Blog – New Releases: Week of July 18, 2017}}{{Cite web|url=http://br.ign.com/99-vidas/50810/news/game-99vidas-sera-lancado-para-ps4-ps3-e-ps-vita |title= 99Vidas release date confirmed for PlayStation Platforms - IGN Brazil(Portuguese)}} on [[PS Store]] for [[PlayStation 4]], [[PlayStation 3]] and [[PlayStation Vita]]. == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:2016 video games]] [[Category:Arcade games]] [[Category:Beat 'em ups]] [[Category:Cooperative video games]] [[Category:Linux games]] [[Category:MacOS games]] [[Category:PlayStation Network games]] [[Category:PlayStation 4 games]] [[Category:PlayStation 3 games]] [[Category:PlayStation Vita games]] [[Category:Multiplayer and single-player video games]] [[Category:Side-scrolling beat 'em ups]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Steam Greenlight games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Brazil]] [[Category:Video games with cross-platform play]]

{{Use Australian English|date=October 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} :''This article concerns the 1982 fictional movie. For information about the actual Commando unit, see [[Z Special Unit]].'' {{Infobox film | name = Attack Force Z | image = Attack Force Z DVD.JPG | caption = [[DVD region code#4|Region 4]] DVD cover | director = [[Tim Burstall]] | producer = {{ubl|[[John McCallum (actor)|John McCallum]]|George F.H. Chang|[[Lee Robinson (director)|Lee Robinson]]}} | writer = [[Roger Marshall (screenwriter)|Roger Marshall]] | starring = {{ubl|[[John Phillip Law]]|[[Mel Gibson]]|[[Sam Neill]]|[[John Waters (actor)|John Waters]]}} | music = [[Eric Jupp]] | cinematography = Hung-Chung Lin | editing = David Stiven | studio = John McCallum Productions | distributor = {{ubl|Jef Films|Roadshow {{small|Australia}}}} | released = {{filmdate|1981|5|18|[[Cannes Film Festival|Cannes]]}}{{filmdate|1982|6|1|Australia}} | runtime = 93 minutes | country = {{ubl|Australia|Taiwan}} | language = English | budget = | gross = $88,000 (Australia) }} '''''Attack Force Z''''' (alternatively titled '''''The Z Men'''''){{cite web | url=https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/3256/Attack-Force-Z/overview | title=Attack Force Z (1982) | work=[[The New York Times]] | author=AMG | accessdate=9 April 2010 }} is a 1981 Australian-TaiwaneseLee, Daw-Ming ''Historical Dictionary of Taiwan Cinema'' Scarecrow Press, 8 November 2012, pp. xxxix-xxxx [[World War II]] film, directed by [[Tim Burstall]]. It is loosely based on actual events and was filmed in [[Taiwan]] in 1979. It was screened at the [[Cannes Film Festival]] on 18 May 1981. The film is noted for starring [[Mel Gibson]] and [[Sam Neill]], who were relatively unknown in the US at the time but who went on to become international stars. The plot concerns Captain P.G. Kelly (Gibson), who leads a team from the elite [[Z Special Unit]] against the [[Empire of Japan]] during the Second World War. The film fictionalises the exploits of the Z Special Unit, which was also known as Z Force. It was a joint Australian, British and New Zealand commando unit. Its main brief was to conduct reconnaissance and sabotage missions throughout Japanese-occupied Southeast Asia. ==Plot== In the Straits of Sembaleng, five men are dispatched by submarine in [[Klepper canoe]]s to rescue survivors of a shot-down plane on a nearby island which is occupied by the [[Imperial Japanese Army]]. Led by Paul Kelly (Gibson), an inexperienced commando officer, the team secretly lands on the island and hides their kayaks. As they venture in land, Ted 'Kingo' King is hit by fire from an unseen machine gun post, the team quickly eliminates the Japanese defenders and return to their wounded comrade. King has been hit on the leg, the bullet smashing his kneecap. King cannot be allowed to fall into enemy hands and compromise the mission under interrogation, and after sharing a cigarette with him, Costello shoots him. The four remaining men return to their search; coming across a rice farmer, they learn of the area in which the plane crashed. The rice farmer is also killed in order to preserve secrecy. But as they near their destination they spot a Japanese squad at a local house, after the Japanese leave they enter the house and meet the local resistance leader Lin, his grown up daughter Chien Hua and her younger brothers and sisters. With a guide to lead them, they head off to the plane but are attacked by Japanese soldiers at a Buddhist temple. Separated from the rest, interpreter Jan Veitch ends up returning to Lin's house where Chien Hua hides him from the returning Japanese. After the deaths of their soldiers, the Japanese officers Watanabe and Imanaka torture Chien to tell them the location of her father, who they believe is hiding the survivors of the crashed plane, but Chien Hua refuses. Lin's son Shaw Hu falsely tells the Japanese that Lin, the Z men, and the plane's survivors are heading for the island's capital. All the Japanese leave except for two soldiers guarding Chien Hua; Veitch kills both with help of Shaw Hu. Meanwhile, within sight of the plane, Kelly watches as locals blow up the wreckage. Lin is evasive, and after quizzing the inhabitants of a village, the team head on to the plane. Kelly manages to get Lin to tell them that the two survivors are being taken to his home, so they turn around and head back. In the capital, Veitch is led to the survivors. One of them is a defecting Japanese government official Imoguchi, and he is believed to hold a secret that could end the war faster. Only Kelly knows that he must be rescued at any cost - or killed. As the pieces of the puzzle begin to fall together, Kelly must persuade his own men that Imoguchi is worth rescuing and the local resistance that it is worth fighting against their Japanese enemies. ==Cast== {{div col}} * [[John Phillip Law]] as Lieutenant J.A. (Jan) Veitch * [[Mel Gibson]] as Captain P.G. (Paul) Kelly * [[Sam Neill]] as Sergeant D.J. (Danny) Costello * [[Chris Haywood]] as Able Seaman A.D. 'Sparrer' Bird * [[John Waters (actor)|John Waters]] as Sub Lt. Ted 'Kingo' King * Ku Chun as Rice farmer * [[Sylvia Chang]] as Chien Hua * O Ti as Shaw Hu * [[Koo Chuan Hsiung]] as Lin Chan-Lang {{div col end}} ==Production== The script was based on a real-life commando rescue raid, [[Operation Opossum]], where a team of commandos rescued the local sultan on the Japanese-held island of [[Ternate]] near Borneo.Sue Johnson, 'After 37 years and 10 beheadings, Operation Rimau Explodes Again', ''Sydney Morning Herald'', 27 March 1982 p 41"Exploits of the men of Z Force relived", ''Sydney Morning Herald'' 6 March 1981 p 8 The film was originally entitled ''The Z Men'' and was to be directed by [[Phillip Noyce]]. Pre production commenced in Taiwan where for six weeks Noyce worked on the script with writer Michael Cove. However, Noyce clashed with the producers - McCallum later claimed in particular that Noyce refused to use one of the Chinese actors who had been cast in a small roleJohn McCallum interview with Brian McFarlane, ''The Oxford Companion to Australian Film'', Oxford Uni Press, 1999 p 300 - and was fired the night before shooting was meant to start. He was replaced by [[Tim Burstall]] in November 1979.{{cite web | url=http://www.channel4.com/film/reviews/film_fact.jsp?id=154796 | title=Attack Force Z | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060528055814/http://www.channel4.com/film/reviews/film_fact.jsp?id=154796 | archivedate=28 May 2006 | publisher=[[Channel 4]] | accessdate=9 April 2010 }}David Stratton, ''The Last New Wave: The Australian Film Revival'', Angus & Robertson, 1980 p39 & 213 Filming was further delayed by constant rain and re-writing of the script.David Stratton, ''The Avocado Plantation: Boom and Bust in the Australian Film Industry'', Pan MacMillan, 1990 p43 Among the changes made were adding a fifth character to the team - a soldier played by John Waters who would be killed within the opening ten minutes by one of their own men.[http://www.signis.net/malone/tiki-index.php?page=Tim+Burstall&bl&PHPSESSID=b84a60315abeb35485367633c6533d29 Interview with Tim Burstall, 30 March 1998] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131115011440/http://www.signis.net/malone/tiki-index.php?page=Tim+Burstall&bl&PHPSESSID=b84a60315abeb35485367633c6533d29 |date=15 November 2013 }} accessed 14 October 2012 ==Reception== ''Attack Force Z'' was only released theatrically in Australia in Melbourne, where it took $88,000 at the box office,[http://film.vic.gov.au/resources/documents/AA4_Aust_Box_office_report.pdf ''Film Victoria - Australian Films at the Australian Box Office''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723234802/http://film.vic.gov.au/resources/documents/AA4_Aust_Box_office_report.pdf |date=23 July 2011 }} which is equivalent to $256,080 in 2009 dollars. After the film's release, Tim Burstall was quoted as saying;
It sold everywhere, sold all over the world, and it got its money back. And it did perform the task of getting some co-productions going with the East, which was useful and very important. But it's always awful when you take over from somebody else - and Phil is a friend - but he really wanted to do something quite different and I was regarded as much more of a whore, I suppose.
Mel Gibson later called the film "pretty woeful... it's so bad, it's funny.""Not just a pretty face In his new movie, Mel debuts as a director -- and puts the hunk on hold", Jay Carr, Globe Staff 22 August 1993 The Boston Globe BSTNGB City Edition B1 John McCallum later said he and Robinson wanted to make another film in Asia, about drug running in Thailand "starting from the poppies and the hill factories where they distil the damned suff and send it down to Bangkok" but were not allowed to make it because of the dangers involved in filming in Thailand. ==See also== * ''[[The Highest Honor]]'' - Another film about Z Special Unit made by the same producers in 1983. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|id=0083591|title=Attack Force Z}} * [http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/attack_force_z/ Attack Force Z at Rotten Tomatoes] * [http://www.ozmovies.com.au/movie/attack-force-z ''Attack Force Z''] at Oz Movies * [https://archive.is/20121130091104/http://colsearch.nfsa.afc.gov.au/nfsa/search/display/display.w3p;adv=yes;group=;groupequals=;holdingType=;page=0;parentid=;query=8228;querytype=;rec=0;resCount=10 Attack Force Z at the National Film and Sound Archive] {{Lee Robinson}} {{Tim Burstall}} [[Category:1981 films]] [[Category:Pacific War films]] [[Category:Australian drama films]] [[Category:Australian films]] [[Category:Australian war films]] [[Category:Taiwanese films]] [[Category:Films based on actual events]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:War adventure films]] [[Category:Films directed by Tim Burstall]]

revision.comment: deleted the word "available" as it was previously used in the sentence. Sorry - - my very first time editing an article.
revision.text:
{{short description|2017 Czech WWII video game}} {{copy edit|date=November 2018}}
'''Attentat 1942''' is a 2017 Czech video game that tells the story of the Nazi occupation of [[Czechoslovakia]] during the [[World War II|Second World War]] through the eyes of the survivors. The game is built on personal memories, interactive comics, and authentic footage. Characters in the game and their stories are fictional, but they are based on personal testimonies and extensive historical research.
The game was developed by scientists from the [[Faculty of Arts, Charles University in Prague|Faculty of Arts]] and the Faculty of Mathematics and Physics of [[Charles University]] and the Institute of Contemporary History of the [[Czech Academy of Sciences]]. ''Attentat 1942'' stems from the educational project ''Czechoslovakia 38-89'', but has been enhanced and further developed for the worldwide public. The game was released for [[Windows]] and Mac on the distributional platform [[Steam (software)|Steam]] on October 31, 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/676630/Attentat_1942/|title=Save 50% on Attentat 1942 on Steam|website=store.steampowered.com|language=en|access-date=2018-09-21}}</ref> The game is available in Czech with English, Russian, and German subtitles and is readily found on several [[Website|websites]].
== Content == ''Attentat 1942'' is a point-and-click adventure game in which players assume the role of the grandchild of Jindřich Jelínek. They discover that his grandfather was arrested by the [[Gestapo]] shortly after the assassination of [[Reinhard Heydrich]], ruler of the Nazi-occupied Czech Lands and leading architect of the Holocaust. The players' goal is to find out the reason why the grandfather was arrested and what role he played in the attack. The players pose questions to the grandmother and other eyewitnesses of those events and slowly discover the story of the family and learn more about life in [[Protectorate of Bohemia and Moravia]].
== Critical reception == The game holds 75% on [[Metacritic]] based on 13 reviews indicating generally favorable reviews.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/attentat-1942|title=Attentat 1942|website=Metacritic|language=en|access-date=2018-09-21}}</ref>
From the reviews:
* "It captivates from start to finish by humanising history brilliantly."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2017/11/03/the-flare-path-czechs-and-choppers/|title=The Flare Path: Czechs and Choppers|work=Rock Paper Shotgun|access-date=2018-09-21|language=en-US}}</ref> * "Attentat 1942 will be a treasure not only for a fresh perspective on a widely reported period of time but also for the amount of work that you can see the developers put into making sure their story fit within the confines of history."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.destructoid.com/review-attentat-1942-481310.phtml|title=Review: Attentat 1942|work=destructoid|access-date=2018-09-21}}</ref> * "Attentat 1942's poignancy managed to stir me on several occasions, and its ending in particular was touching."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.digitallydownloaded.net/2017/12/review-attentat-1942-pc.html|title=Review: Attentat 1942 (PC)|last=S|first=Matt|website=www.digitallydownloaded.net|access-date=2018-09-21}}</ref> * "Attentat 1942, as a game, is an excellent meld of historical documentary authenticity and solid genre gameplay."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://gamingthepast.net/2017/11/24/attentat-1942-review/|title=Attentat 1942 – Review|date=2017-11-24|work=Gaming the Past|access-date=2018-09-21|language=en-US}}</ref> * "Attentat 1942 does a beautiful job exploring a tragedy with all the respect and sensitivity that its survivors are due."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://gamecritics.com/rebekah-ocker/attentat-1942-review/|title=Attentat 1942 Review – GameCritics.com|website=gamecritics.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-21}}</ref>
== Awards ==
* "Most Amazing Game" at A MAZE festival in Germany<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://amaze-berlin.de|title=A MAZE. / Berlin – April 25–29, 2018|author=A MAZE. staff|accessdate=2018-09-21}}</ref> * "Best Learning Game" at [[Games for Change]] in USA<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://variety.com/2018/gaming/news/games-for-change-2018-awards-1202861602/|title=‘Life Is Strange: Before the Storm’ Wins Big at Games for Change Awards|last=Fogel|first=Stefanie|date=2018-06-29|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|access-date=2018-09-21}}</ref> * "Excellence in Narrative" nomination at [[Independent Games Festival]] in USA<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.igf.com/article/2018-independent-games-festival-announces-main-competition-finalists|title=2018 Independent Games Festival announces Main Competition finalists!|date=2018-01-02|work=IGF|access-date=2018-09-21|language=en}}</ref> * Second place at the Game Development World Championship in Finland<ref>{{Cite web|author=Game Development World Championship|title=Game Development World Championship Winners 2017|date=2017-11-29|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r7lLLBLd0wg|access-date=2018-09-21}}</ref> * [[Czech Game of the Year Awards|Czech Game Of The Year 2017]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ceskahraroku.cz/vysledky-2017/|title=Výsledky 2017 - ČESKÁ HRA ROKU 2017|work=ČESKÁ HRA ROKU 2017|access-date=2018-09-21|language=cs-CZ}}</ref> * "Educational Game" at [[The Independent Game Developers' Association]] Awards 2018 in UK<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://tiga.org/awards/2018-winners|title=2018 Winners|date=2018-11-01|work=[[The Independent Game Developers' Association]]|access-date=2018-11-02}}</ref>
== Controversy == The game was released worldwide on [[Steam (software)]] on October 2017, except in Germany where it was blocked due to the German practice of not giving ratings to games containing Nazi symbolism. On May 2018, ''Attentat 1942'' won the "Most Amazing Game" Award at the A MAZE festival in Berlin, but the visitors could not play it. They could only watch a censored trailer with no Nazi symbolism included. Meanwhile, the jury played the game behind closed doors.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://gamasutra.com/blogs/JrgFriedrich/20180817/324775/Were_making_the_first_game_that_legally_shows_Nazi_symbols_in_Germany__heres_why_you_should_care.php|title=We're making the first game that legally shows Nazi symbols in Germany – here’s why you should care|access-date=2018-09-21|language=en}}</ref> In August 2018, the policy of [[Unterhaltungssoftware Selbstkontrolle|USK]], the authority providing age ratings for video games, was changed and now allows that games with Nazi symbolism to receive age ratings, depending on their individual "social adequacy." ''Attentat 1942'' was therefore released in Germany as the first PC game with Nazi symbolism with the USK age rating received after the policy change.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://gamasutra.com/view/pressreleases/326142/Attentat_1942_a_video_game_unavailable_due_to_Nazi_symbolism_finally_released_in_Germany.php|title=Attentat 1942, a video game unavailable due to Nazi symbolism, finally released in Germany|access-date=2018-09-21|language=en}}</ref>
== References == <references />

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Sport in Iceland]]; added [[Category:Sport in Iceland by sport]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Update|date=May 2016}} '''Australian Rules Football''' is played by three clubs in Iceland, with the Andspyrnusamband Íslands (Icelandic Australian Football League - IceAFL) being the main league and controlling body for the sport. The IceAFL was founded in 2009, and regular competition commenced in 2010. The league is the world's most northerly Australian Rules Football league.[http://www.worldfootynews.com/article.php/20100514220001958 Iceland's Fosters Premiership kicks off this weekend]. == History == Australian rules football has been played in [[Iceland]] since 20 May 2009, when Friðgeir Torfi Ásgeirsson, who had played in the [[Danish Australian Football League]], placed an ad in a local newspaper and put up flyers at pubs and schools around Reykjavik looking for players.[http://www.theroar.com.au/2009/06/12/no-longer-just-aussie-ex-pats/ AFL spreads its wings thanks to ex-pat efforts]. A group of seven people gathered that afternoon at the far end of the Reykjavik Pond. Before the first club was founded in Iceland, a national team, named the Icelandic Ravens, had been assembled for the [[2009 EU Cup Australian rules football|2009 EU Cup]].{{cite web|author=Aaron Richard|url=http://www.worldfootynews.com/article.php/20090831205520610 |title=EU Cup 2009 - Team Profiles on |publisher=Worldfootynews.com |date= |accessdate=29 October 2010}} The first teams were founded in April 2010 and are known as the Dragons, Eagles and Bulls. The team names come from Iceland's coat of arms,{{cite web|url=http://www.andspyrna.is/about-the-team/saga-asi |title=Saga ASÍ |publisher=Andspyrna.is |date= |accessdate=29 October 2010}} leaving the Giant as the only symbol unaccounted for. The current (2017) president is Friðgeir Torfi Ásgeirsson. == Clubs == There are three clubs currently playing Australian Rules Football in Iceland. They play each other in the nine-a-side IceAFL league. The league was founded in 2009 by Friðgeir Torfi Ásgeirsson, who is the current league president. In its inaugural year 2010, the IceAFL league was named the IceAFL Fostersleague after its main sponsor. '''The Bulls''' Eyjólfur Bjarni Sigurjónsson, having taken over as National Coach{{cite web|author=Aaron |url=http://www.worldfootynews.com/article.php/20100723160327818 |title=Iceland from kick in the park to Euro Championships in under 12 months |publisher=Worldfootynews.com |date= |accessdate=29 October 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.andspyrna.is/about-the-team |title=Um ASÍ |publisher=Andspyrna.is |date= |accessdate=29 October 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ec2010.info/participants/icelandic-ravens |title=Iceland from kick in the park to Euro Championships in under 12 months |publisher=Ec2010.info |date=24 July 2010 |accessdate=29 October 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721200245/http://www.ec2010.info/participants/icelandic-ravens |archivedate=21 July 2011 |df=dmy }} from Friðgeir Torfi Ásgeirsson, founded the Bulls and captained them. In the Icelandic AFL's inaugural year the Bulls won the double by winning both the pre-season Cup Tournament{{cite web |url=http://www.sport.is/ithrottir/2010/05/02/gri%C3%B0ungarnir-sigurvegarar-i-astrolskum-ru%C3%B0ningi/ |title=Griðungar sigurvegarar í andspyrnu |publisher=Sport.is |date= |accessdate=29 October 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726003850/http://www.sport.is/ithrottir/2010/05/02/gri%C3%B0ungarnir-sigurvegarar-i-astrolskum-ru%C3%B0ningi/ |archive-date=26 July 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} and the domestic league.{{cite web|url=http://www.mbl.is/mm/frettir/forsida/2010/09/18/meistarar_i_andspyrnu/ |title=Meistarar í andspyrnu |publisher=Mbl.is |date=18 September 2010 |accessdate=29 October 2010}} '''The Dragons''' The Dragons were founded by Jón Zophoníasson, who captained and coached the team until after the European Championships 2010, when Viðar Valdimarsson took over as coach. In the spring of 2012 the Dragons moved north to Akureyri and are currently (summer of 2012) managed by Sölvi Fannar Sigmarsson, and coached by Jón Hrói Finnsson. '''The Eagles''' The Eagles were founded by national team captain and league founder Friðgeir Torfi Ásgeirsson.http://aflcommunityclub.com.au/index.php?id=51&tx_ttnews[tt_news]=72&cHash=7733edebbf == The National Team == The Icelandic national team is nicknamed the Ravens and participated in two international competitions in its first year of existence. The Ravens reached the 9PO at the EU Cup 2009, beating the EU Crusaders to take home the EU Cup Bowl.{{cite web|url=http://www.aussierulesinternational.com/home/tournaments/eu-cup/2009/results |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-12-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716094656/http://www.aussierulesinternational.com/home/tournaments/eu-cup/2009/results |archivedate=16 July 2011 |df=dmy }} In its second outing, Iceland, along with players from France, played in the inaugural full-field Australian Rules European Championships in Denmark and Sweden. After losses to hosts Denmark and Great Britain, Iceland defeated Finland before losing to Croatia, and ultimately finished in sixth place.{{cite web|url=http://ec2010.info/match-reports/46-finals-5po-croatia-vs-iceland |title=Finals - 5PO - Croatia vs Iceland |publisher=Ec2010.info |date=8 August 2010 |accessdate=29 October 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110105074710/http://www.ec2010.info/match-reports/46-finals-5po-croatia-vs-iceland |archivedate=5 January 2011 |df=dmy }} In the 2012 Euro Cup, after losing against Norway in the Euro Plate final, they ended up in overall 14th place. == List of Icelandic Champions == 2010: Bulls
2011: Bulls
2012: Eagles
2013: Bulls/Eagles (combined team)
2014: Eagles
2015: Bulls
2016: no league competition
2017: no league competition == List of Icelandic Cup winners == 2010: Bulls (2 games won, 0 lost). No national cup tournament has been held since 2010 == Arctic Cup == Iceland is a founding member of the Arctic Cup Tournament and the inaugural tournament was hosted by Iceland in 2017.http://mpegmedia.abc.net.au/news/audio/am/201703/20170325-am08-icelandafl.mp3 == List of Best and Fairest == 2009 Leifur Bjarnason (based on games with the national team, as no league had been officially formed yet).
2010 Leifur Bjarnason
2011 Leifur Bjarnason
2012 Leifur Bjarnason
2013 Leifur Bjarnason
2014 Leifur Bjarnason
2015 Leifur Bjarnason
2016 N/A (No league competition)
2017 N/A (No league competition) == References == {{Aussie Rules Playing Nations links}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Australian Rules Football in Iceland}} [[Category:Australian rules football by country]] [[Category:Sport in Iceland by sport]]

revision.comment: Robot - Moving category 2008 Summer Olympic venues to [[:Category:Venues of the 2008 Summer Olympics]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2018 October 19]].
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Infobox swimming venue |name = Beijing National Aquatics Centre |logo = WaterCubeLogo.svg |logosize = 200px |logocaption = |image = Beijing_National_Aquatics_Centre_1.jpg |imagesize = |caption = The National Aquatics Center, with the [[Beijing National Stadium]] in the background |fullname = Beijing National Aquatics Center |nicknames = Water Cube |city = [[Beijing]], [[China]] |capacity = 6,000 (17,000 during Olympics) |built = 2004–2007 |opened = 2008 |construction cost = [[Renminbi|CNY]]940 million
[[United States dollar|USD]]140 million
[[Euro|EUR]]94 million |architects = [[PTW Architects]], [[China State Construction Engineering Corp|CSCEC]], [[China Construction Design International|CCDI]], and [[Arup Group Limited|Arup]] |home clubs = |poolname = Main pool |length = {{convert|50|m|ft|abbr=on}} |width = {{convert|25|m|ft|abbr=on}} |deep = {{convert|3|m|ft|abbr=on}} |lanes = 10 |}} The '''Beijing National Aquatics Center''' ({{zh|t=北京國家游泳中心|s=北京国家游泳中心|p=Běijīng guójiā yóuyǒng zhōngxīn|altname=Beijing National Aquatics Center}}), also officially known as the '''National Aquatics Center''',Official Olympics Site [http://en.beijing2008.cn/venues/nac/index.shtml National Aquatics Center] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080809120236/http://en.beijing2008.cn/venues/nac/index.shtml |date=August 9, 2008 }} and colloquially known as the '''Water Cube''' ({{zh|s=水立方|altname=Water Cube}}), is an aquatics center that was built alongside [[Beijing National Stadium]] in the [[Olympic Green]] for the [[Swimming at the 2008 Summer Olympics|swimming competitions of the 2008 Summer Olympics]]. Despite its nickname, the building is not an actual cube, but a [[cuboid]] (a rectangular box). Ground was broken on December 24, 2003, and the Center was completed and handed over for use on January 28, 2008.[http://en.beijing2008.cn/cptvenues/venues/nac/headlines/n214241273.shtm National Aquatics Center Delivered for Use]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Beijing 2008 Olympics Official Web Site, January 1, 2008, Swimmers at the Water Cube [[Swimming at the 2008 Summer Olympics#Records broken|broke 25 world records]] during the 2008 Olympics.{{cite web|title=25 world records broken at Beijing's Water Cube |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/26268614/ |date=August 18, 2008 |author=Scott M. Reid |publisher=[[Orange County Register]] and [[MSNBC]] }}{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} After the 2008 Olympics the building underwent a 200 -million yuan revamp to turn half of its interior into a water park.{{cite web|title=Cube becomes Park for Olympic Revival|url=http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90782/92900/6887960.html}} The building officially reopened on August 8, 2010.{{cite web |last=Farrar |first=Lara |title=Beijing's Water Cube now has slides, rides, a wave pool and spa |url=http://www.cnngo.com/explorations/play/beijings-watercube-water-park-now-open-040746?hpt=C2 |publisher=CNNGO |accessdate=August 15, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100819120011/http://www.cnngo.com/explorations/play/beijings-watercube-water-park-now-open-040746?hpt=C2 |archivedate=August 19, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }} It will host the curling at the [[2022 Winter Olympics]]. ==Architecture== In July 2003 the Water Cube design was chosen from 10 proposals in an international [[architectural design competition|architectural competition]] for the aquatic center project.{{cite web |last=Arup East Asia |title=The Water Cube, National Aquatics Centre, Beijing |url=http://www.arup.com/eastasia/project.cfm?pageid=1250 |accessdate=August 17, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080604115637/http://www.arup.com/eastasia/project.cfm?pageid=1250 |archivedate=June 4, 2008 |df=mdy }} The Water Cube was specially designed and built by a [[consortium]] made up of [[PTW Architects]] (an Australian [[architecture firm]]),{{cite web|url=http://www.ptw.com.au/ptw_project/watercube-national-swimming-centre/|title=Water Cube - National Swimming Centre|work=PTW Architects|accessdate=August 5, 2015}} [[Arup Group Limited|Arup]] international engineering group, CSCEC ([[China State Construction Engineering Corp]]oration), and CCDI ([[China Construction Design International]]) of Shanghai.[https://www.theguardian.com/science/2004/may/06/research.science1 Welcome to WaterCube, the experiment that thinks it's a swimming pool] by Peter Rogers in The Guardian, May 6, 2004 The Water Cube's design was initiated by a team effort: the Chinese partners felt a square was more symbolic to Chinese culture and its relationship to the [[Beijing National Stadium|Bird's Nest]] stadium, while the Sydney-based partners came up with the idea of covering the 'cube' with bubbles, symbolising water. Contextually the cube symbolises earth whilst the circle (represented by the stadium) represents heaven. Hence symbolically the water cube references Chinese symbolic architecture. Comprising a steel [[space frame]], it is the largest [[ETFE]]-clad structure in the world with over 100,000 m² of ETFE pillows that are only 0.2 mm (1/125 of an inch) in total thickness.{{Cite journal |last=arup.com | title=Best of What's New 2006 – Engineering | journal=Popular Science |volume=269 |issue=6 | year=2006 | url=http://www.popsci.com/popsci/flat/bown/2006/product_41.html | page=84–85 |postscript=}} The ETFE [[cladding (construction)|cladding]], supplied and installed by the firm [[Vector Foiltec]], allows more light and heat penetration than traditional glass, resulting in a 30% decrease in energy costs. The outer wall is based on the [[Weaire–Phelan structure]], a structure devised from the [[Patterns in nature|natural pattern]] of bubbles in soap lather.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/olympics/7069401.stm Beijing venues – National Aquatics Center], on BBC Sports. In the true Weaire-Phelan structure the edge of each cell is curved in order to maintain 109.5 degree angles at each vertex (satisfying [[Plateau's rules]]), but of course as a structural support system each beam was required to be straight so as to better resist axial [[compression (physical)|compression]]. The complex Weaire–Phelan pattern was developed by slicing through bubbles in soap foam, resulting in more irregular, organic patterns than foam bubble structures proposed earlier by the scientist [[William Thomson, 1st Baron Kelvin|Kelvin]]. Using the Weaire–Phelan [[geometry]], the Water Cube's exterior cladding is made of 4,000 ETFE bubbles, some as large as {{convert|9.14|m}} across, with seven different sizes for the roof and 15 for the walls.{{cite journal | last = Pearson | first = Clifford | title = Projects: National Swimming Center | journal = Architectural Record | volume = 196 | issue = 7 | publisher = McGraw Hill | date = July 2008 | url = http://archrecord.construction.com/projects/portfolio/archives/0807nationalswimming-1.asp | accessdate =August 16, 2008 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080813094645/http://archrecord.construction.com/projects/portfolio/archives/0807nationalswimming-1.asp| archivedate= August 13, 2008 | deadurl= no}} The structure had a capacity of 17,000 during the games that is being reduced to 7,000. It also has a total land surface of 65,000 square meters and will cover a total of {{convert|32000|m2|acre}}. Although called the Water Cube, the aquatic center is really a [[Cuboid|rectangular box (cuboid)]] {{convert|178|m}} square and {{convert|31|m}} high. The building's popularity has spawned many copycat structures throughout China.[[Barbara Demick]]. [http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-beijing-cube14-2009aug14,0,6430709.story "Beijing's Water Cube Still Drawing Crowds"]. ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''. Aug. 13, 2009. For example, there is one-to-one copy of the facade near the ferry terminal in [[Macau]] – the ''Casino Oceanus'' by [[Paul Steelman]].[http://www.oceanus.asia/ Casino Oceanus – The Unofficial Casino Oceanus Website from ''www.oceanus.asia''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110201204824/http://www.oceanus.asia/ |date=February 1, 2011 }} File:Water Cube The National Aquatics Center Chaoyang Beijing.jpg|Water Cube The National Aquatics Center in [[Chaoyang (Beijing)|Chaoyang]] File:国家游泳中心夜景.jpg|The National Aquatics Center at night File:Cubeinside.jpg|Inside the Water Cube on August 14, 2008 File:National Aquatics Center Construction.jpg|The Beijing National Aquatics Center while under construction ==2008 Olympics== The Aquatics Center hosted the swimming, diving, and [[synchronized swimming]] events during the Olympics. [[Water polo]] was originally planned to be hosted in the venue but was moved to the [[Ying Tung Natatorium]]. Many people believed the Water Cube to be the fastest [[Olympic-size swimming pool|Olympic pool]]{{cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=93478073|title=China's Olympic Swimming Pool: Redefining Fast|date=August 10, 2008|work=NPR|first1=Howard|last1=Berkes|accessdate=August 5, 2015}} in the world. It is 1.314 meters deeper than most Olympic pools. The [[London Aquatics Centre|London 2012 Aquatics Centre]] is the same depth, which leads many to believe the London pool is as fast as, if not faster than, the Beijing pool. Up to a certain limit, beyond which swimmers will lose their sense of vision, deeper pools allow the waves to dissipate to the bottom, leading to less water disturbance to the swimmers. The pool also has perforated gutters on both sides to absorb the waves.{{Citation needed|date=March 2013}} The Aquatics Center saw [[Swimming at the 2008 Summer Olympics#Records broken|25 world records broken]] in the [[2008 Summer Olympics|Beijing Olympics]]; however, [[List of world records in swimming|all the records broken]] were accomplished by athletes using the [[High-technology swimwear fabric|super-slick swimwear]] which has become banned at the beginning of the 2010 season by the [[FINA|International Swimming Federation]] (FINA).{{cite news|last1=Crouse|first1=Karen|title=Swimming Bans High-Tech Suits, Ending an Era|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/25/sports/25swim.html|accessdate=August 5, 2015|work=The New York Times|date=July 24, 2009}} ==Post-Olympics usage== [[File:Watercube-Aquacube-Cubed'eau-水立方-2010.ogv|thumb|right|Video: The Beijing National Aquatics Center reopened on July 28, 2010.]] After the Olympics, the Water Cube was opened to the public on select days of the week beginning in June 2009, and was also used as the site for a production of ''[[Swan Lake]]'' amongst other shows. On October 19, 2009, the Water Cube was closed to the public to begin a massive renovation of a portion of the complex into a [[water park]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ebeijing.gov.cn/BeijingInformation/BeijingNewsUpdate/t1089220.htm|title=Water Cube will close for renovation from October 15|work=eBeijing, the Official Website of the Beijing Government|accessdate=August 5, 2015}} The building reopened on August 8, 2010, marking the second anniversary of the beginning of the 2008 Summer Olympics. The redesigned facility contains numerous water rides and slides, a wave pool, and spa areas. The renovations were performed in order to bring renewed interest to the [[Olympic Green]] area as part of the games' legacy. ==2022 Winter Olympics== {{expand section|date=August 2015}} The Water Cube will be used for curling during the 2022 Winter Olympic Games.{{cite web|url=http://www.sportspromedia.com/news/beijing_to_host_2022_winter_olympic_games|title=Beijing to host 2022 Winter Olympic Games|work=Sports Pro Media|first1=Eoin|last1=Connolly|date=July 31, 2015|accessdate=August 5, 2015}} ==Awards== {{quote|The special award for the most accomplished work in the section Atmosphere is awarded to the Australian architecture firm PTW Architects, CSCEC + Design and Arup for the project National Swimming Centre, Beijing Olympic Green, China. The project demonstrates in a stunning way, how the deliberate morphing of molecular science, architecture, and phenomenology can create an airy and misty atmosphere for a personal experience of water leisure|Quote from the Jury report of the Official Awards 9th International Architecture Exhibition – METAMORPH, Venice Biennale}} * 2004: [[Venice Biennale]] – Award for most accomplished work Atmosphere section{{cite web|url=http://www.ptw.com.au/index.html |title=PTW Projects:Watercube-National Swimming Centre |accessdate=December 6, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060819090901/http://ptw.com.au/index.html |archivedate=August 19, 2006 |df=mdy }}(page in Flash presentation) * 2006: ''[[Popular Science]]'' Best of what's new 2006 in engineering * 2008: [[NSW]] Project of the Year award from the Australian Institute of Project Management{{cite web|last1=Lee|first1=Ellen|title=Water Cube scoops the pool at project management awards|url=http://www.arup.com/News/2008-09%20September/09-09-08-Water_Cube_scoops_the_pool_at_project_management_awards|website=Arup|accessdate=August 5, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923174333/http://www.arup.com/News/2008-09%20September/09-09-08-Water_Cube_scoops_the_pool_at_project_management_awards|archivedate=September 23, 2015|df=mdy-all}} * 2009: 40th annual [[MacRobert Award]], the UK's biggest prize for engineering innovation * 2010: [[International Association for Bridge and Structural Engineering]] 2010 [[Outstanding Structure Award]] == See also == {{Portal|Beijing|Architecture}} *[[Frei Otto]] *[[Chris Bosse]] *[[Rob Leslie-Carter]] *[[Swimming at the 2008 Summer Olympics]] *[[Swimming at the 2008 Summer Paralympics]] *[[Curling at the 2022 Winter Olympics]] *[[Wheelchair Curling at the 2022 Winter Paralympics]] *[[Timothy Schreiber]] == References == {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== article describing the design of the building and the mathematics behind it] *[http://www.designbuild-network.com/projects/watercube News and Project Information on the Watercube, Beijing]
