{{unreferenced|date=June 2008}} {{use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} '''German underground horror''' is a subgenre of the [[horror film]], which has achieved cult popularity since first appearing in the mid-1980s.
Horror films produced by the German underground scene are usually trademarked by their intensity, taking on topics that are culturally taboo such as [[rape]], [[necrophilia]], and [[extreme violence]]. Films that glorify violence are not technically [[Law|illegal]] in [[Germany]], but certain titles are banned by the government and [[Zollkriminalamt]]. Distribution, import, or creation of specific films can constitute steep fines.
== History of German underground horror ==
In an attempt to shed its violent image, horror films were very rarely made in Germany after the fall of the [[Third Reich]]. Movies such as ''[[Horrors of Spider Island]]'', ''[[The Blood Demon]]'', and ''[[The Head (film)|The Head]]'' were filmed and released in the decades following [[World War II]], but to very little success.
In 1987, filmmaker [[Jörg Buttgereit]] wrote and directed ''[[Nekromantik]]''. Two years later, amateur filmmaker [[Andreas Schnaas]] made the movie ''[[Violent Shit]]'' for a reported $2000. Released as Germany's first [[direct-to-video]] film, it was a modest hit amongst fans of independent horror. Both films were banned by the [[German government]], but their popularity influenced other filmmakers such as [[Olaf Ittenbach]] to bring Germany's underground horror film scene further into the media spotlight.
Since then, many other filmmakers have emerged from the German underground horror scene, including [[Uwe Boll]] and [[Timo Rose]]. Uwe Boll is notable as the only underground German director who has gone on to a career in big budget cinema.
== Ratings' effect on German underground horror ==
Once a film has been rated by the [[Freiwillige Selbstkontrolle der Filmwirtschaft|German ratings board]], that is its rating for both cinema and video releases. It is legal to have two versions of a film. Often, there is a cut "FSK 16" version (equivalent to the [[Motion Picture Association of America film rating system|R-rating]] by the [[MPAA]]) released in cinemas and an uncut "FSK 18" version (equivalent to an [[NC-17]] rating) on video. Films rated "FSK 18" are not stocked by all video shops, which affects rentals of violent German horror.
In Germany, there is also a category above "FSK 18" entitled "indiziert" or "on the index". "Indizierte" films are treated the same way as pornography. Distribution companies, cinemas, and video shops cannot advertise these films, nor can they be openly on display—unless a shop is open to "adults only". However, it is legal to sell and buy such material. Many video rental stores have back rooms or basements for such merchandise.
Examples of "indizierte" films include ''[[Cannibal Ferox]]'', ''[[Cannibal Holocaust]]'', ''[[The Last House on the Left (1972 film)|Last House on the Left]]'', ''[[From Dusk Till Dawn]]'', and [[Dario Argento]]'s ''[[Profondo Rosso]]'' (Deep Red). Several of these films were released uncut in Germany, but were subject to the limitations listed. Others were edited and then released as "indiziert".
Some movies, e.g. ''[[Braindead (film)|Braindead]]'', are completely banned in Germany (mostly for glamorizing violence), as it is illegal even to sell them to adults. These movies are "indiziert" as well as "beschlagnahmt" ("judicially confiscated"). While selling these kinds of media is strictly prohibited, it is legal to buy or own such movies.
{{Film genres}}
[[Category:Film genres]] [[Category:German culture]] [[Category:German horror films|*]]

{{rewrite|date=June 2016}} {{Infobox video game |title = Grendel's Cave |image = [[Image:GrendelsCaveLogo.gif]]
''Grendel's Cave'' Logo |developer = Grendel Enterprises, L.L.C. |publisher = |designer = |engine = |released = August 1, 1998 |genre = [[Real-time game#Real-time|Real-time]] [[Video game genres#Adventure|Adventure]] |modes = Multiplayer |platforms = Web }} '''''Grendel's Cave''''' was a [[Real-time game#Real-time|real-time]] browser-based [[role-playing video game]] and [[MUD]]. Grendel Enterprises published and ran it exclusively on the [[Internet]]. The basis for ''Grendel’s Cave'' was [[Anglo-Saxons|Anglo-Saxon]] [[Anglo-Saxon paganism|mythology]] and [[Beowulf]], and it was set in the historical [[Middle Ages|medieval period]]. Scholars considered it an artistic depiction of [[Grendel]] and the poem, Beowulf, as well as a modern adaptation and a derivative work of the epic. Educational websites use ''Grendel's Cave'' as an Internet learning aid for [[medieval literature]] and they considered it an online Beowulf resource. ==Literary significance== ''Grendel's Cave'' was an online Beowulf resource that goes beyond the written text by allowing players to participate in the story. {{Citation | last = Wray | first = David | title = Literacy: Major Themes in Education | place = | publisher = RoutledgeFalmer | origyear = | year = 2004 | month= | volume = IV: Literacy: New literacies, the impact of technology | edition = | chapter = | chapterurl = | page = 208 | pages = | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=yJikbMX_-BQC&pg=PA208&dq=grendelscave.com&hl=en&ei=rB8ZTIryJ8P98Abcm9H9AQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=grendelscave.com&f=false | doi = | id = | isbn = 0-415-27712-4}} Scholars consider it a modern adaptation of the original Beowulf poem. {{Citation |last = Sutton |first = John William |title = BEOWULFIANA: MODERN ADAPTATIONS OF BEOWULF |work = [[University of Rochester]]: Rossell Hope Robbins Library |url = http://www.lib.rochester.edu/camelot/BeowulfBooklet.htm |accessdate = 16 June 2010 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081019032929/http://www.lib.rochester.edu/camelot/BeowulfBooklet.htm |archivedate = 19 October 2008 |df = }} [[Glencoe/McGraw-Hill|Glenco McGraw-Hill]] uses the site as part of their Study Guide for Beowulf. {{Citation | last = | first = | title = Study Guide for Beowulf: A translation by Burton Raffel | place = | publisher = [[Glencoe/McGraw-Hill]] | origyear = | year = | month= | volume = | edition = | chapter = | chapterurl = | page = 4 | pages = | url = http://www.glencoe.com/sec/writerschoice/litlibrary/pdf/beowulf.pdf | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20030630210737/http://www.glencoe.com/sec/writerschoice/litlibrary/pdf/beowulf.pdf | archivedate =2003-06-30 | doi = | id = | dead-url = yes | isbn = 0-07-823546-4}} Educational websites use ''Grendel's Cave'' as an online reference for medieval literature. {{Citation | last = Balser | first = Walter F. | author-link = | title = SchoolAtlas Academic Database | date = | year = | url = http://www.schoolatlas.com/search2/English/English_Literature/Medieval_Literature/index1.html | accessdate = 17 June 2010}} ==History== Mars Software Products wrote the first version of ''Grendel's Cave'' in 1981 as a [[single-player video game]] for the [[SWTPC]] 6800 [[microcomputer]]. This version was a fully [[text-based game]] but included many of the features of the later Internet incarnations of the game. The developer based the game on an older [[Role-playing game (pen and paper)|pen and paper dungeon game]] with the same name. In 1997, Grendel's Net took over the project and began development of an Internet version of the game. Grendel's Net conducted their development as an experiment in [[Active Server Pages|Classic ASP]] and [[Microsoft]] [[Microsoft SQL Server|SQL]] 6.0 programming for the [[World Wide Web]]. They rolled out Version 1.0 in August 1998. This version ran until July 2001. [[Hacker (computer security)|Hacking]] and [[Cheating in video games|cheats]] plagued this version during the last year of its run, which finally brought about the demise of the game. {{Cite news | last = Vanderwater | first = Kurt | title = Oklahoma Programmers Give Life to Literary Online Game | work = The Worx Company | date = 7 June 2010 | url = http://worxco.com/blog/oklahoma-programmers-give-life-literary-online-game | accessdate = 17 June 2010}} In early 2005, Grendel Enterprises acquired the rights to all of Grendel's Net assets. Grendel Enterprises' programmers found the original ''Grendel's Cave'' [[source code]] on an old [[database server]] in an office closet. Soon after, they started work on ''Grendel's Cave'' v2.0. They rolled out the first [[beta version|beta]], v1.8A, on April 1, 2005 and over the next two years followed it up by four more pre-2.0 [[Software release life cycle|versions]], 1.8B, 1.8C, 1.9, and 2.0 betas. Finally, on November 11, 2007, version 2.0 went live. Version 2.0 contained many aspects of the original ''Grendel's Cave'' with the addition of many [[Norse mythology|Norse mythological]] elements and [[Non-player character|NPCs]]. {{Cite news | last = Cook | first = John | title = ''Grendel’s Cave'' Interview: Looking at a Classic Browser Based Game | work = Raven Leaf | date = 26 January 2009 | url = http://www.ravenleaf.com/grendelscave/GrendelsCaveInterview.pdf | accessdate = 22 August 2014}} The game’s graphics have remained mostly unchanged throughout its history, giving it and old and outdated look. {{Cite news | last = Webster | first = Blake | title = A Review of ''Grendel's Cave'' | work = Raven Leaf | date = 21 April 2010 | url = http://www.ravenleaf.com/grendelscave/GrendelsCaveReview.pdf | accessdate = 22 August 2014}} Version 3.0 added text only and MUD style user interfaces, [[Audio game#TTS-enabling video games|TTS-enabling]] the game. Grendel's Cave has effectively shut down. ==Gameplay== Gameplay involves creating [[Thegn|Thanes]], the [[player character]]s in the game, killing [[monster]]s, primarily found in ''Grendel's Cave'', increasing value and stats and collecting items. Thanes obtain gold rings, the game's currency, by selling obtained items or Singing of Deeds before King [[Hroðgar|Hrothgar]]. They gain magical abilities by visiting the [[Witch]] or through acquired items. Ultimately, this leads players to complete quests and earn [[amulet]]s, by traveling to other worlds, and trading in those earned amulets for the [[Yggdrasil]] amulet and thus gaining the ability to kill Grendel. Killing Grendel is the ultimate objective of the game. After killing Grendel there is a secondary objective, killing [[Grendel's Mother]], and then a tertiary objective, killing [[The Dragon (Beowulf)|The Dragon]]. At any one time there are many kingdoms running, with a Grendel in each kingdom that players can kill, of several different kingdom types. The different kingdom types range from beginner to advanced, with increasing difficulty and requirements for killing Grendel, occasionally tournament style or championship kingdoms and personal kingdoms that can be custom configured by individual players. The less advanced kingdoms are generally non-[[Player versus player|PVP]], while the more advanced kingdoms allow PVP and player killing. Killing Grendel in any of the more advanced kingdoms earns the player's Thane a place on the hall of fame. To date 202 Thanes have earned a spot on the hall of fame. ==Plot and setting== The basis for ''Grendel's Cave'' is the Anglo-Saxon poem, Beowulf. It is set in King Hrothgar's, king of the [[Danes]], kingdom in the early 6th century. The kingdom is in the middle of its war with Grendel. Grendel is an [[Intelligent agent|AI]] monster, who performs many tasks, most of them nasty, involving killing or harassing Thanes in the game. It contains many Norse mythology elements but also contains [[Anachronism|anachronistic]] elements as well as many references to historical events and items and [[popular culture]]. It encompasses [[Norse cosmology]], with each of the nine worlds represented in the game. Player's Thanes can travel to these worlds and complete quests. Thanes can take on other than human characteristics, including [[Valkyrie]], [[Berserker]]s, [[Trickster]]s, and [[Shapeshifting|Shape-Shifters]], among others. ==Versions== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Daily Cash Prizes |} == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{Official website|www.grendelscave.com/}} {{Beowulf|collapsed}} [[Category:1998 video games]] [[Category:Adventure games]] [[Category:Beowulf]] [[Category:Browser-based multiplayer online games]] [[Category:Entertainment websites]] [[Category:Fantasy video games]] [[Category:History educational video games]] [[Category:Indie video games]] [[Category:Top-down video games]] [[Category:Video games based on novels]] [[Category:Video games developed in the United States]] [[Category:Video games based on Norse mythology]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox writer <!-- for more information see [[:Template:Infobox writer/doc]] --> | name = Horia Gârbea | image = | imagesize = | caption = | pseudonym = | birth_date = August 10, 1962 | birth_place = [[Bucharest]] | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = playwright, essayist, journalist, poet, publisher, screenwriter | nationality = Romanian | period = 1982–present | genre = [[free verse]], [[lyric poetry]], [[parody]], [[satire]], [[tragicomedy]] | subject = | movement = ''[[Optzecişti]]'', [[Postmodern literature|Postmodernism]], [[Neorealism (art)|Neorealism]] | influences = [[Radu Albala]], [[Tudor Arghezi]], [[Jorge Luis Borges]], [[Ion Luca Caragiale]], [[Mateiu Caragiale]], [[Anton Chekhov]], [[Ion Creangă]], [[Ştefan Augustin Doinaş]], [[Umberto Eco]], [[Gustave Flaubert]], [[Ioan Groşan]], [[Eugène Ionesco]], [[James Joyce]], [[Franz Kafka]], [[Nicolae Manolescu]], [[Mircea Martin]], [[Gellu Naum]], [[Costache Negruzzi]], [[Jean-Paul Sartre]] | influenced = | signature = | website = }}
'''Horia-Răzvan Gârbea''' or '''Gîrbea''' ({{IPA-ro|ˈhori.a rəzˈvan ˈɡɨrbe̯a}}; born August 10, 1962) is a Romanian playwright, poet, essayist, novelist and critic, also known as an academic, engineer and journalist. Known for his work in [[experimental theater]] and his [[Postmodern literature|Postmodernist]] contributions to [[Literature of Romania|Romanian literature]], he is a member of the [[Writers' Union of Romania]] (USR), its [[public relations]] executive and the head of its [[Bucharest]] chapter. Also recognized for his contribution to [[Romanian humor]] and his essays, he has published regularly in journals such as ''[[Contemporanul]]'', ''[[Luceafărul (magazine)|Luceafărul]]'', ''[[Ramuri]]'' and ''[[Săptămâna Financiară]]''. His career in the media also covers [[screenwriting]] for [[Television in Romania|Romanian television stations]] and the popularization of [[contract bridge]]. The author of several scientific works on engineering, Gârbea is also a faculty member at the [[University of Agronomical Sciences and Veterinary Medicine]].
The recipient of several national awards for literature, he received critical attention for plays, short stories and novels which merge [[intertextuality]] and [[parody]] with [[Neorealism (art)|neorealistic]] elements. In his work for the [[Theatre of Romania|Romanian stage]], Gârbea has primarily reworked motifs from [[Anton Chekhov]], [[Ion Luca Caragiale]], [[Gustave Flaubert]], [[Costache Negruzzi]] and various other of his predecessors, addressing contemporary realities. He is also the other of [[Tragicomedy|tragicomedies]] with themes borrowed the [[Romanian Revolution of 1989|1989 Revolution]] and his country's [[History of Romania since 1989|post-1989 history]]. The latter focus is complemented by his works in novel and short prose, which often take the form of [[political fiction]] or [[satire]] aimed at his writer colleagues. Such contributions have consolidated Gârbea's success with the general public, but have divided critical opinion on the issue of their ultimate literary value.
==Biography==
===Early life and career=== Born in [[Bucharest]], Horia Gârbea is the grandson of [[Titus Gârbea]], a [[Romanian Land Forces|Land Forces]] general and diplomat of the [[Kingdom of Romania|Romanian Kingdom]].<ref name="abprofesia">{{ro icon}} Alina Boboc, [http://www.revista22.ro/bucurestiul-cultural-15-78part2-4922.html "Profesia de scriitor are nevoie de recunoaştere"], in ''[[Revista 22]]'', Nr. 973, October 2008</ref><ref name="bbcradem">{{ro icon}} Bianca Burţa-Cernat, [http://www.observatorcultural.ro/Sa-ridem-cu-Horia-Garbea*articleID_16567-articles_details.html "Să rîdem cu Horia Gârbea?!"], in ''[[Observator Cultural]]'', Nr. 348, November 2006</ref> He recalls that his grandfather's passion for literature was passed onto him from an early age, when he first heard him reciting poems by [[Dante Aligheri]].<ref name="abprofesia"/> The future writer attended the [[Mihai Viteazul High School]], opting for a sciences-based curriculum, but envisioned becoming a writer.<ref name="hgmeseria">Horia Gârbea, [http://www.revista22.ro/bucurestiul-cultural-20-83-part-i-5740.html "Meseria de a scrie (la comandă)"], in ''[[Revista 22]]'', Nr. 992, March 2009</ref> At around age 17, as one of the adolescent guests on a [[Romanian Television]] [[talk show]] hosted by author [[Mircea Sîntimbreanu]], he stated his intention of having two books published by the year 2000 (he recalls: "[Sîntimbreanu], who was a witty but skeptical man, did not encourage me").<ref name="hgmeseria"/>
Gârbea made his debut in 1982, at age twenty, his poems being published by the student magazine ''Amfiteatru''.<ref name="hgmeseria"/><ref name="asprea-pl">{{ro icon}} [[Alex. Ştefănescu]], [http://atelier.liternet.ro/articol/4654/Alex-Stefanescu-Horia-Garbea/Un-prea-plin-al-inspiratiei-o-voiosie-literara.html "Un prea-plin al inspiraţiei, o voioşie literară"], at [[Editura LiterNet]], June 13, 2007; retrieved September 9, 2009</ref> He graduated from the [[University of Agronomical Sciences and Veterinary Medicine|Agronomical Science University]]'s Department of [[Landscape engineering|Landscaping]] and [[Environmental engineering|Environmental Engineering]] (1986).<ref name="cvusr">{{ro icon}} [http://www.uniuneascriitorilor.ro/Garbea%20CV.htm ''Curriculum Vitae''], at the [[Writers' Union of Romania]] site; retrieved September 9, 2009</ref> A member of the teaching staff at his ''[[alma mater]]'' since 1987,<ref name="bbcradem"/> he received a [[Doctor of Science]] diploma from the [[Politehnica University of Bucharest|Politehnica University]] in 1999.<ref name="cvusr"/> A regular of ''Cenaclul de luni'' ("The Monday Literary Club"), founded by literary critic [[Nicolae Manolescu]] and journalist [[Radu Călin Cristea]],<ref name="hgmeseria"/><ref name="garevpc">{{ro icon}} [[Gabriela Adameşteanu]], [http://www.revista22.ro/revista-presei-culturale-62.html "Revista presei culturale"], in ''[[Revista 22]]'', Nr. 630, April 2002</ref> Gârbea later moved on to the ''Universitas'' circle, founded and led by critic [[Mircea Martin]].<ref name="hgmeseria"/> His early poetry was awarded a 1986 prize by Spain's [[University of the Basque Country|University of Bilbao]] (1986).<ref name="bbcradem"/><ref name="cvusr"/>
A turning point in Horia Gârbea's writing career was the [[Romanian Revolution of 1989]], which put an end to the [[Communist Romania|communist regime]]. In 1990, one of his first works in [[drama]], translated into English as ''The Serpent'', was performed by the British [[Royal Court Theatre]].<ref name="cvusr"/> A year later, ''Pescăruşul din livada cu vişini'' ("The Seagull in the Cherry Orchard") was first staged at the [[Victor Ion Popa]] Theater, followed in 1992 by the premiere of ''Funcţionarul destinului'' ("The Clerk of Destiny") with the Bucharest [[experimental theater]] company Inoportun.<ref name="cvusr"/> He made his editorial debut in the genre with the 1993 volumes ''Doamna Bovary sînt ceilalţi'' ("[[Madame Bovary]] Are the Others") and ''Mephisto'' (a [[Romanian-language]] variant of [[Klaus Mann]]'s [[Mephisto (novel)|1936 novel]]).<ref name="cvusr"/><ref name="andespre">{{ro icon}} [[Alina Nelega]], [http://www.observatorcultural.ro/Despre-Matei-VISNIEC-Saviana-STANESCU-Radu-MACRINICI...*articleID_3170-articles_details.html "Despre Matei Vişniec, Saviana Stănescu, Radu Macrinici..."], in ''[[Observator Cultural]]'', Nr. 57, March 2001</ref> Another one of his plays, ''Stăpânul tăcerii'' ("The Master of Silence"), was staged in 1994 by [[Piteşti]]'s [[Alexandru Davila]] Theater.<ref name="cvusr"/>
Gârbea's first volume of [[lyric poetry]], {{lang|ro|Text biografic}} ("Biographical Text"), saw print in 1996, earning him an award granted by the [[Sighetu Marmaţiei International Poetry Festival|Sighet Poetry Festival]].<ref name="cvusr"/> Also that year, the writer followed up with a second collection of poems, ''Proba cu martori'' ("The Confrontation of Witnesses"), which was awarded the yearly prize of the Bucharest Association of Writers (a section of the USR).<ref name="cvusr"/> In 1996, he wrote the script for ''Ils emménagement'' ("They Are Moving On"), a [[French-language]] [[street theater]] performance, which premiered in France.<ref name="cvusr"/> ''Proba cu martori'' was followed in 1997 by the short story volume ''Misterele Bucureştilor'' ("The Mysteries of Bucharest") and the multiple award-winning novel ''Căderea Bastiliei'' (Romanian for "[[Fall of the Bastille]]").<ref name="asprea-pl"/><ref name="cvusr"/><ref name="pacarnav">{{ro icon}} [[Paul Aretzu]], [http://revistaramuri.ro/index.php?id=192&editie=13 "D-ale carnavalului literaturii"], in ''[[Ramuri]]'', August 10, 2007</ref>
Gârbea returned to drama with the 1999 book ''Decembrie, în direct'' ("December, Live Broadcast").<ref name="cvusr"/><ref name="rcsecurit">{{ro icon}} [[Ruxandra Cesereanu]], [http://www.phantasma.ro/caiete/caiete/caiete1/19.html "Imaginea Securităţii în literatura română în comunism şi postcomunism. Studiu de caz"], in ''Caietele Echinox'', Vol. 1, 2001, at the [[Babeş-Bolyai University]]'s [http://phantasma.ro/ Center for Imagination Studies]</ref> It received the Writers' Union Prize for Theater.<ref name="cvusr"/> The student theater company Calandrinon featured his ''Cărţile'' ("The Books") in its 2000 program,<ref name="cvusr"/> and the [[Toma Caragiu Theater]] in [[Ploieşti]] did the same with ''Cafeaua domnului Ministru'' ("The Minister's Coffee").<ref name="cvusr"/><ref name="mmginditi">{{ro icon}} Mihaela Michailov, [http://www.observatorcultural.ro/Ginditi-Domnule-Ministru*articleID_4033-articles_details.html "Gîndiţi, Domnule Ministru!"], in ''[[Observator Cultural]]'', Nr. 43-44, December 2000</ref> In 2001, he published an [[anthology]] of texts for the stage: titled ''Cine l-a ucis pe Marx?'' ("Who Killed [[Karl Marx|Marx]]?"), it was a recipient of the [[Romanian Academy]]'s [[Ion Luca Caragiale]] Award with a three-year delay.<ref name="cvusr"/><ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.observatorcultural.ro/Premii-peste-premii%C3%A2%E2%82%AC%C5%9A*articleID_9947-articles_details.html "Premii peste premii..."], in ''[[Observator Cultural]]'', Nr. 201-202, January 2004</ref> Also in 2001, his short story collection {{lang|ro|Enigme în oraşul nostru}} ("Enigmas in Our City") saw print.<ref name="asprea-pl"/><ref name="cvusr"/><ref name="pacarnav"/><ref name="dsbpostm">{{ro icon}} [[Dan-Silviu Boerescu]], [http://www.cuvantul.ro/articol/?artID=34&nr=296 "Postmodernismul sau soluţia finală" (XXX)], in ''[[Cuvântul (literary magazine)|Cuvântul]]'', Nr. 296</ref> These were followed the next year by ''Raţă cu portocale'' ("[[Duck à l'Orange]]"), a volume of essays, and, in 2003, by two other books: ''Vacanţă în infern'' ("A Holiday in Hell"; literary criticism, 2 vols.)<ref name="asprea-pl"/><ref name="cvusr"/> and ''Creşterea iguanelor de casă'' ("Raising Pet [[Iguana]]s"; poetry).<ref name="asprea-pl"/><ref name="cvusr"/><ref name="notexte">{{ro icon}} Nicolae Oprea, [http://www.ziua.net/display.php?id=152716&data=2004-07-17 "Texte poetice"], in ''[[Ziua]]'', July 17, 2004</ref> The former was shortlisted for the USR Award.<ref name="cvusr"/>
His career in the post-Revolution press began early in 1990, when he was among the writers published by ''Nouăzeci'', a magazine founded by [[Laurenţiu Ulici]], [[Cristian Popescu (writer)|Cristian Popescu]] and [[Cătălin Ţârlea]].<ref>{{ro icon}} UN Cristian, [http://www.observatorcultural.ro/Ioan-Es.-Pop-A-inceput-sa-mi-pese-de-viata*articleID_20192-articles_details.html "Ioan Es. Pop: 'A început să-mi pese de viaţă' "], in ''[[Observator Cultural]]'', Nr. 434, July 2008</ref> Active as a theater critic and chronicler,<ref name="abprofesia"/> as well as a [[contract bridge]] popularizer,<ref name="hgmeseria"/><ref name="dc-ejoc">{{ro icon}} [[Daniel Cristea-Enache]], [http://www.romlit.ro/un_joc_de_societate "Un joc de societate"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 34/2008</ref> he later had permanent columns in ''[[Luceafărul (magazine)|Luceafărul]]'' (1990–1995, and again 1998-2001), ''ArtPanorama'' (1997–1998), ''Scena'' (1998–2001), ''[[Monitorul de Iaşi]]'' (1998–1999), ''[[Contemporanul]]'' (1999–2001), ''[[Săptămâna Financiară]]'' (after 2005)<ref name="cvusr"/> and the [[Craiova]]-based literary magazine ''[[Ramuri]]''.<ref name="abprofesia"/><ref name="blorbitor">{{ro icon}} Beatrice Lăpădat, [http://www.observatorcultural.ro/Debut.-Orbitor-Aripa-nebuna*articleID_20053-articles_details.html "Debut. Orbitor – Aripa nebună"], in ''[[Observator Cultural]]'', Nr. 430, July 2008</ref> His articles were also published by other venues, among them ''[[Convorbiri Literare]]'', ''[[Cuvântul (literary magazine)|Cuvântul]]'', ''[[România Literară]]'' and ''[[Ziarul Financiar]]''.<ref name="cvusr"/> In 2001, he joined the editorial staff of ''Okean'', a specialized magazine co-founded by three Romanian theater companies: [[Bulandra Theatre|Bulandra]], [[Nottara Theatre|Nottara]], [[Odeon Theatre (Bucharest)|Odeon]] and the [[National Theater Cluj-Napoca]].<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.observatorcultural.ro/Numarul-2/2001-al-revistei-de-teatru-Okean*articleID_3406-articles_details.html "Numărul 2/2001 al revistei de teatru ''Okean''"], in ''[[Observator Cultural]]'', Nr. 54, March 2001</ref> He was also among the first Romanian authors to publish fiction in the new wave of [[lifestyle magazine]]s, being an early contributor to the local version of ''[[Playboy]]'' (together with [[George Cuşnarencu]], [[Răzvan Petrescu]] and [[Jean Lorin Sterian]]).<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Marius Chivu]], [http://www.dilemaveche.ro/index.php?nr=282&cmd=articol&id=11003 "Literatură glossy"], in ''[[Dilema Veche]]'', Vol. VI, Nr. 282, July 2009</ref> Between 2002 and 2003, he published several works related to his field of expertise in engineering: ''Structuri şi construcţii cu izolatori dinamici'' ("Structures and Constructions with Dynamic Insulation", 2002), ''Structuri şi construcţii – noţiuni şi calcule de fiabilitate'' ("Structures and Constructions—Notions and Calculations in Reliability", 2002), ''Structuri şi construcţii – curs universitar'' ("Structures and Constructions—University Lecture", 2003; revised edition 2004).<ref name="cvusr"/>
===Literary consecration and Writers' Union activities=== An active member of the Writers' Union since 1994, Horia Gârbea was elected president of its Bucharest chapter in 2003, and appointed head of the Union's [[public relations]] branch two years later.<ref name="bbcradem"/><ref name="cvusr"/> As a representative of the Bucharest section, he worked closely with Editura Nouă publishing house in helping to popularize the writings of his fellow association members.<ref name="abprofesia"/> Having joined the [[UNITER]] association of theatrical professionals in 1993, he also works as a [[dramaturge]], and has first been employed as such by the Toma Caragiu Theater since 1998.<ref name="cvusr"/> His contributions in this field include translations and adaptations of plays by [[Anton Chekhov]] (''[[The Cherry Orchard]]''), [[Pierre Corneille]] (''[[L'Illusion comique]]''), [[Dario Fo]] (''[[We Won't Pay! We Won't Pay!]]''), [[Pierre de Marivaux]] (''[[Le Triomphe de l'amour]]''), [[Molière]] (''[[The School for Wives]]''), [[Ayn Rand]] (''[[Night of January 16th]]''), [[Fernando Arrabal]], [[Jacques Copi]], [[Eugène Ionesco]], [[John D. MacDonald]], [[Niccolò Machiavelli]], [[Gérald Sibleyras]], [[Tennessee Williams]] and [[Stanisław Ignacy Witkiewicz]].<ref name="cvusr"/> In 1998, Gârbea also began working in [[screenwriting]], collaborating with several national television stations. He was first employed by [[Pro TV]] from 1998 to 2001, working on the [[variety show]] ''Ministerul comediei'' and the [[sitcom]] ''La Bloc''.<ref name="cvusr"/> He was then affiliated with [[Prima TV]], writing for [[Romică Ţociu]] and [[Cornel Palade]]'s ''Alomania'' [[sketch comedy]] show, and later [[Naţional TV]], where he contributed to a similar production, ''Naţionala de bere''.<ref name="cvusr"/> In 2001, Gârbea was also involved in writing for [[Antena 1 (Romania)|Antena 1]]'s sitcom ''Clanul Popeştilor''.<ref name="cvusr"/> Between 2002 and 2003, he worked with the public broadcaster [[TVR Cultural]], where he hosted a [[talk show]] on cultural issues.<ref name="cvusr"/>
During 2004, authors Horia Gârbea, [[Valeriu Butulescu]], [[Mircea Ghiţulescu]] and [[Mircea Petean]] traveled to [[Vietnam]], on the invitation of the [[Vietnamese Writers Union]].<ref name="lvnghean">{{ro icon}} Lucia Verona, [http://www.sfin.ro/articol_1413/citeste.html "Citeşte!"], in ''[[Săptămâna Financiară]]'', June 30, 2005</ref> Their experience in the [[Far East]] produced the collective travel account ''Drumul spre Nghe An'' ("The Road to [[Nghe An Province|Nghe An]]"), published the same year.<ref name="cvusr"/><ref name="lvnghean"/> Also in 2004, Gârbea premiered his ''Cleopatra a şaptea'' ("[[Cleopatra VII]]") with the [[Andrei Mureşanu Theatre|Andrei Mureşanu company]] of [[Sfântu Gheorghe]], published a new work for the stage—''Hotel [[Miguel de Cervantes|Cervantes]]'', and oversaw the publishing of [[Editura Limes]]' ''Repetiţie fără orchestră'' ("Rehearsal without an Orchestra"), an anthology of prose pieces by young Romanian authors.<ref name="cvusr"/> His own work also included the 2005 essay collections ''Arte parţiale'' ("Partial Arts") and ''Bridge în 41 de povestiri vesele'' ("Contract Bridge in 41 Cheerful Stories").<ref name="cvusr"/> Gârbea was made Knight of ''[[Meritul Cultural]]'' order through a 2004 [[President of Romania|presidential]] decree.<ref name="cvusr"/> In March 2005, as head of the Bucharest Association of Writers, he set up the Romanian version of France's literary festival ''Le Printemps des Poètes'' ("Poets' Spring", known locally as ''Primăvara poeţilor'').<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.revista22.ro/bucuresti-linie-de-orizont-1598.html "''Primăvara poeţilor'' la Paris şi la Bucureşti"], in ''[[Revista 22]]'', Nr. 783, March 2005</ref> A month later, during the ''Romanian Comedy Festival'', his play ''Leonida XXI'' was staged by the [[Comedy Theatre, Bucharest|Comedy Theater]].<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://adevarul.md/articole/2005/ce-haz-mai-are-comedia-romaneasca.html "Ce haz mai are comedia românească?"], in ''[[Adevărul]]'', April 5, 2005</ref>
Also in 2005, Gârbea and the Writers' Union were involved in a polemic with [[Paul Goma]], a novelist and former [[dissident]] who lives in France. This came after ''[[Viaţa Românească]]'', a literary magazine managed by the Union, republished fragments from Goma's diary, which caused public outrage for its perceived [[antisemitism]].<ref name="diversscandal">{{ro icon}} [http://www.divers.ro/actualitate_ro?wid=37455&func=viewSubmission&sid=3000 ''Scandal la USR''], at [http://www.divers.ro/ Divers.ro], September 15, 2005; retrieved September 9, 2009</ref><ref name="mgmanolescu">{{ro icon}} Manuela Golea, [http://www.gardianul.ro/index.php?pag=nw&id=66411 "Manolescu îl acuză pe Goma de antisemitism"], in ''[[Gardianul]]'', September 2, 2005</ref><ref name="osviata">{{ro icon}} [[Ovidiu Şimonca]], [http://www.observatorcultural.ro/A-devenit-Viata-Romaneasca-o-revista-antisemita*articleID_13902-articles_details.html "A devenit ''Viaţa Românească'' o revistă antisemită?"], in ''[[Observator Cultural]]'', Nr. 286, September 2005</ref> Gârbea and USR president [[Nicolae Manolescu]] both intervened to sanction the publication. In an early interview with ''[[Gardianul]]'' daily, he spoke of the editorial staff as having displayed "negligence", and noted that replacing the panel of editors was one of the sanctions being considered, while also stating that he felt none of them were "100% responsible" for the incident.<ref name="mgmanolescu"/> Gârbea however dismissed rumors that he and his colleagues were considering disestablishing ''Viaţa Românească'', noting that the magazine was a historical institution.<ref name="mgmanolescu"/>
The USR's public expression of regret over having tolerated "a text with antisemitic content" caused Goma to threaten with a lawsuit on [[libel]] grounds.<ref name="diversscandal"/><ref name="osviata"/> In reaction, Gârbea stated: "What we are interested in is ''Viaţa Românească'', a press organ edited by the USR. Paul Goma may believe whatever he likes. It is not him that we are discussing, but the magazine. I see no reason why he would sue me personally."<ref name="diversscandal"/> According to an overview of the episode by journalist [[Ovidiu Şimonca]], Horia Gârbea had unwittingly prompted Goma to state his intention of suing the [[History of the Jews in Romania|Jewish-Romanian]] community league, or [[Federation of Jewish Communities of Romania]] (FCER). This was because, during the scandal, Gârbea had explained that the FCER's reaction was an incentive in the USR's internal investigation.<ref name="osviata"/> Goma's claim for reparations from FCER leaders, Şimonca noted, ignored the fact that Gârbea had not disclosed any names.<ref name="osviata"/>
===Since 2006=== Gârbea published his second novel, ''Crime la Elsinore'' ("Murders at [[Helsingør]]"), in 2006.<ref name="pacarnav"/><ref name="cccaderea">{{ro icon}} [[Cosmin Ciotloş]], [http://www.romlit.ro/cderea_elsinore-ului "Căderea Elsinore-ului"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 46/2006</ref> Printed the same year, his new drama volume, ''Divorţ în direct'' ("Live Divorce"), was nominated for another USR award.<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.revista-apostrof.ro/articole.php?id=238 "Nominalizări pentru premiile Uniunii Scriitorilor pe anul 2006"], in ''[[Apostrof]]'', Nr. 4/2007</ref> In late 2007, he participated with fellow writers [[Doina Ruşti]] and [[Liviu Ioan Stoiciu]] in a [[children's literature]] project initiated by [[Editura Paralela 45]], which involved rewriting a series of [[fairy tales]] in [[Folklore of Romania|Romanian folklore]] and [[Christian mythology]].<ref name="evcopii">{{ro icon}} Elena Vlădăreanu, [http://www.romanialibera.ro/a114324/literatura-pentru-copii-intre-harry-potter-si-clasici.html "Literatura pentru copii, între Harry Potter şi clasici"], in ''[[România Liberă]]'', December 27, 2007</ref> Titled ''Basme şi poveşti mistice româneşti repovestite'' ("Retold Romanian Fairy Tales and Mystical Stories"), it was illustrated with reproductions of children-made [[Romanian icons]].<ref name="evcopii"/> His son, Tudor, was born in the same year.<ref name="abprofesia"/><ref name="dc-ejoc"/>
With the 2008 ''Trecute vieţi de fanţi şi de birlici'' ("Bygone Lives of Beaus and Aces"), he investigated the history of [[Literature of Romania|Romanian literature]] by focusing on and inventorying literary types.<ref name="abprofesia"/><ref name="dc-ejoc"/><ref name="sdpitor">{{ro icon}} Silvia Dumitrache, [http://www.observatorcultural.ro/Viata-pitoreasca-a-personajelor*articleID_20807-articles_details.html "Viaţa pitorească a personajelor"], in ''[[Observator Cultural]]'', Nr. 450, November 2008</ref><ref name="emscriitori">{{ro icon}} [[Emil Mladin]], [http://www.viataromaneasca.eu/arhiva/57_viata-romaneasca-1-2-2009/10_cronici/254_scriitori-personaje-cititori.html "Scriitori, personaje, cititori..."], in ''[[Viaţa Românească]]'', Nr. 1-2/2009</ref> In spring, he participated in the project ''Scriitori pe calea regală'' ("Writers on the Royal Road"), organized by the former [[King of Romania]] [[Michael I of Romania|Michael I]], the [[Romanian Royal Family|Royal House]], the USR and various other venues for the benefit of award-winning writers.<ref name="abprofesia"/> He was also the USR's envoy to the Three Seas Writers and Translators Committee conference on [[Rhodes]], Greece.<ref name="abprofesia"/>
The same year, Gârbea voluntarily reduced his contributions to drama and theater criticism, citing his family obligations, alongside a general disappointment with the milieu: "I grew aware that writing for the theater is usually not followed by productions. Although plays I signed were constantly performed, I never had productions at a satisfactory level nor significant material gains, except for translations."<ref name="abprofesia"/> Instead, he focused on writing a [[Fantasy literature|fantasy]] novel for the youth, ''Făt Frumos din lună'' ("''[[Făt Frumos]]'' from the Moon") and a cycle of poems known as ''Cântecele lui Huppy'' ("Huppy's Songs"), as well as on reviewing for publishing the [[memoir]]s of his grandfather [[Titus Gârbea]].<ref name="abprofesia"/> Working with Editura Tritonic publishing house, Gârbea also coordinated an anthology of [[political fiction]], in which he included his own [[novella]] ''Detestarea naţiunii'' ("Detesting the Nation").<ref name="abprofesia"/>
In 2010, Editura Limes published ''Fratele mai deştept al lui Kalaşnikov'' ("[[Mikhail Kalashnikov|Kalashnikov]]'s Smarter Brother"), his new volume of short prose.<ref name="atfratele">{{ro icon}} [[Andrei Terian]], [http://www.zf.ro/ziarul-de-duminica/fratele-mai-destept-al-lui-kalasnikov-6139593 "''Fratele mai deştept al lui Kalaşnikov''"], in ''[[Ziarul Financiar]]'', May 20, 2010</ref> The same year, Gârbea visited [[Azerbaijan]], invited by the [[Heydar Aliyev Foundation]], and published some of his impressions in ''[[Revista 22]]''.<ref>{{ro icon}} Horia Gârbea, [http://www.revista22.ro/articol-8928.html "Azerbaidjan – Ţara Focului viu. Unde se termină lumea?"], in ''[[Revista 22]]'', Nr. 1072, September 2010</ref> His larger [[travel writing]], published by the same foundation as ''Azerbaijan - The Living Flame'' (in English, [[Romanian language|Romanian]], German), was officially launched at the [[Frankfurt Book Fair]] (October 2010).<ref name="trendflame">[http://wap.trend.az/en/page4/1761968/ "Frankfurt to host book launch of ''Azerbaijan – The Living Flame''"], [[Trend News Agency]] release, October 6, 2010; retrieved January 7, 2010</ref> In April 2011, Gârbea and fellow writer [[Ruxandra Cesereanu]] were in Israel, attending the Nisan Poetry Festival in [[Maghar, Israel|Maghar]].<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Ruxandra Cesereanu]], [http://www.romlit.ro/poezie_n_ara_sfnt "Poezie în Ţara Sfântă"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 17/2011; Horia Gârbea, [http://www.revistaluceafarul.ro/index.html?id=3375&editie=141 "Festivalul 'Nisan' 2011"], in ''[[Luceafărul (magazine)|Luceafărul]]'', Nr. 20-21/2011</ref>
==Work==
===Cultural context and Postmodernist reinterpretations=== Committed to [[Postmodern literature|Postmodernism]], Gârbea debuted as a member of the ''[[Optzecişti]]'' group of writers, most of whom reached their creative peak after 1980: together with [[Mircea Cărtărescu]], [[Traian T. Coşovei]], [[Florin Iaru]], [[Doru Mareş]], [[Radu G. Ţeposu]] and [[Ion Stratan]], he was part of the ''Optzecişti'' nucleus inside ''Cenaclul de luni''.<ref name="garevpc"/> Given his relatively late consecration, Gârbea is nevertheless identified with the 1990s generation of post-''Optzecişti''.<ref name="bbcradem"/><ref name="dsbpostm"/><ref name="notexte"/><ref name="dc-ejoc"/><ref name="egppachet">{{ro icon}} [[Emilian Galaicu-Păun]], [http://www.sud-est.md/numere/20071231/article_5/ "Carte la pachet-2007"], in ''[[Revista Sud-Est]]'', Nr. 4/2007</ref> This also reflects Gârbea's own positioning: according to his own statement, the move from one generation group to the other coincided with his leaving ''Cenaclul de luni'' and joining ''Universitas''.<ref name="hgmeseria"/> In 2008, he expressed much criticism for ''[[Orbitor]]'', a large-scale novelistic cycle by the ''Optzecişti'' group leader Cărtărescu.<ref name="blorbitor"/> In her critical overview of Gârbea's contributions, ''[[Observator Cultural]]'' chronicler Bianca Burţa-Cernat describes him as one among the lesser authors of the 1990s generation, alongside [[Dan-Silviu Boerescu]] and [[Mihail Gălăţanu]].<ref name="bbcradem"/> Writing for the 2007 [[Columbia University]] ''Encyclopedia of Modern Drama'', Romanian-born Israeli actor-director [[Moshe Yassur]] included Gârbea "among the best known" of post-1989 playwrights "experimenting with post-[[Theatre of the Absurd|absurd]]-[[surrealism|surrealist]] modes of expression."<ref name="myromania">Moshe Yassur, "Romania", in Gabrielle H. Cody, Evert Sprinchorn (eds.), ''The Columbia Encyclopedia of Modern Drama'', [[Columbia University Press]], New York & Chichester, 2007, p.1150. {{ISBN|978-0-231-14424-7}}</ref> Others in this group are, according to his definition, [[Radu Macrinici]], [[Alina Mungiu-Pippidi]], [[Alina Nelega]], [[Saviana Stănescu]], [[Matei Vişniec]] and [[Vlad Zografi]].<ref name="myromania"/> In a 2001 overview of the generation's contribution, Nelega herself mentioned Gârbea and the others alongside [[Valentin Nicolau]] and [[Răzvan Petrescu]].<ref name="andespre"/>
A defining characteristic of Gârbea's main works is the reliance on [[intertextuality]], as compliments to his predecessors in drama, novel and poetry.<ref name="bbcradem"/><ref name="asprea-pl"/><ref name="andespre"/><ref name="pacarnav"/><ref name="dsbpostm"/><ref name="notexte"/><ref name="madrazb">{{ro icon}} [[Mircea A. Diaconu]], [http://www.ziua.ro/display.php?data=2003-02-10&id=109928 "Horia Gârbea. Răzbunarea teatrului"], in ''[[Ziua]]'', February 10, 2003</ref><ref name="ospotop">{{ro icon}} [[Octavian Soviany]], [http://ziua.net/display.php?data=2002-11-11&id=104394 "Potopul şi parodia"], in ''[[Ziua]]'', November 11, 2002</ref> Speaking in 2009, Gârbea himself recalled his stylistic discovery of the 1980s: "It still seemed to me that being a writer meant having visions and struggling to communicate them so that others may have them too. [...] I could not write prose, but I enjoyed writing drama because I had invented something very fun to do: old characters in new situations."<ref name="hgmeseria"/> Poet and critic [[Octavian Soviany]] noted: "Horia Gârbea is a dramatist who builds with a program in mind, placing his stake on the resources of [[parody]] and the intertextual play. The parodic here is given birth by the disabused conscience of a postmodern spirit, who knows that all books have been written and therefore only their 'rewriting' [...] is still possible".<ref name="ospotop"/> Commenting on the texts grouped within ''Cine l-a ucis pe Marx?'', literary critic [[Mircea A. Diaconu]] placed the intertextual references (which often make a point of transgressing historical reality) in connection with [[William Shakespeare]]'s phrase "[[All the world's a stage]]", since "everything is possible at the level of the text becoming reality".<ref name="madrazb"/> He praises the author for managing to preserve an "absence that imposes", by not making his own intervention felt in the text.<ref name="madrazb"/> Diaconu admits that such an approach could be read as "gratuitously bookish, [where] a line is more important than an event, a pun more important than a murder", but supports the notion that they all display an "[[Existentialism|existential]] bearing", accounting for an "intrinsic value."<ref name="madrazb"/> He speaks of the technique as "a vengeance of the theater" on the traditional historical record: "In essence, Horia Gârbea's theater emerges from the textual inconsistency of the world when faced with the consistency of history, or, better yet, from the inconsistency of history and the textual consistency of the world."<ref name="madrazb"/>
===Generic traits and related polemics=== Beyond its immediate context, critics see Horia Gârbea's contribution as greatly indebted to the work of 19th century dramatist and humorist [[Ion Luca Caragiale]]. According to Diaconu, Caragiale's influence constitutes the "depth" of Gârbea's work, going beyond the "surface level" of intertextual references and tributes.<ref name="madrazb"/> At the same core level, Diaconu identifies the author's debt to [[Eugène Ionesco]], while also judging his manner of "mixing eras, languages, writings, characters or historical figures, fiction and document" to echo the techniques of [[Argentina|Argentinian]] writer [[Jorge Luis Borges]].<ref name="madrazb"/> Another main influence on Gârbea's work is [[interwar]] author [[Mateiu Caragiale]], made famous by his cultivated style and eccentric outlook.<ref name="duistorii">{{ro icon}} Dumitru Ungureanu, [http://www.observatorcultural.ro/index.html/articles|details?articleID=10757 "Istorii 'albalate' "], in ''[[Observator Cultural]]'', Nr. 218, April 2004</ref> Critic Dumitru Ungureanu sees this cultural echo as having been filtered by the style of [[Radu Albala]], one of the authors to have been most inspired by the "matein" narratives, and concludes that the lineage places Gârbea on the same level as Cărtărescu and [[Florin Şlapac]].<ref name="duistorii"/>
According to his generation colleague, essayist Dan-Silviu Boerescu, Gârbea "cannot part with the speculative charm of a brain given to bookish games", but closely follows a realistic tradition with his "sarcastic analysis of [...] all everyday weakness."<ref name="dsbpostm"/> For Boerescu, Gârbea's literature is supported by his sarcasm and his contribution to [[Romanian humor]]: "Thin and edgy like a razor, Gârbea's style forgives no one no thing."<ref name="dsbpostm"/> Soviany also argues that the "rewriting" of texts attempted by the Romanian author is carried by "[[absurd humor]]" and "the most unusual (as well as the most hilarious) arrangements of famous characters and quotes".<ref name="ospotop"/> Poet and critic [[Paul Aretzu]] writes: "The staple of [Horia Gârbea's] writing is inventive, farcical, the obvious attribute of intelligence and refinement, also displaying bookish support and being enhanced by zestful language. [...] The tendency of visualizing, of sketching portraits, of detailing/dissecting scenes, of verifying [[orality]], the expressive value of the language, reveal the author's dominant structure as a playwright."<ref name="pacarnav"/> The alternation of such stylistic traits reflects in part the writer's own parting with the ''Optzecişti''. The focus on everyday issues prompted [[Cătălin Ţârlea]] to view Gârbea's 1990s prose as a revival of [[Neorealism (art)|neorealism]] after the ''Optzecişti'' [[Experimental literature|experimentalism]].<ref name="dsbpostm"/> Boerescu however believes this verdict to be "only half right", since the writer continued to employ experimental devices long after 1989, while avoiding the "referential ostentation" of other writers.<ref name="dsbpostm"/> Appreciation of Gârbea's work was also expressed among older critics and Gârbea's own mentors. [[Nicolae Manolescu]] held Gârbea's contribution in high esteem, an, in his 2008 synthesis of Romanian literary history, spoke of him as having "indisputably, the fabric of a dramatist".<ref name="bcesecul">{{ro icon}} [[Bogdan Creţu]], [http://www.cuvantul.ro/articol/?artID=18&nr=383 "Eşecul lui Nicolae Manolescu" (II)], in ''[[Cuvântul (literary magazine)|Cuvântul]]'', Nr. 383</ref>
In Nelega's view, Gârbea, "one of the truly alive writers of his time", was among the few debuting local playwrights to have their works staged by prominent Romanian directors—[[Alexandru Darie]], [[Alexandru Hausvater]] and [[Gavril Pinte]].<ref name="andespre"/> Gârbea's fellow ''[[România Literară]]'' contributor, literary historian [[Alex. Ştefănescu]], contrasted his writings with the "boring" works by some of his contemporaries, and claimed that "directors and actors take pleasure in staging [Gârbea's plays]."<ref name="asprea-pl"/> Gârbea's work stands out within its cultural and temporal context for its size and diversity. Aretzu sees him as "one of the most ubiquitous authors in present-day literature, [...] gifted with a great availability in processing reality",<ref name="pacarnav"/> while critic and academic Nicolae Oprea believes him to be "the most prolific" among the Bucharest-based group formed in the 1990s.<ref name="notexte"/> Literary reviewer [[Daniel Cristea-Enache]] also describes his colleague as "multilateral" who "can adapt himself with great ease to any particular genre's specificity".<ref name="dc-ejoc"/> Writing in 2007, Ştefănescu defined him a "one-man orchestra [...] of the apathetic (and sometimes shy-brazen) Romanian literature of today."<ref name="asprea-pl"/> According to [[Moldova]]n writer [[Emilian Galaicu-Păun]]: "As productive as an entire literary school [...], Horia Gârbea is a veritable [[Stakhanovite]] of writing, who has dealt in all genres and species".<ref name="egppachet"/> Gârbea is also among the post-1990 Romanian authors to have received recognition abroad. In addition to the performances of ''The Serpent'' and ''Il émmagement'', Gârbea's ''Raţă cu portocale'' has been translated into German by Veronika Dreichlinger (''Ente mit Apfelsine'', published in 2005).<ref name="abprofesia"/><ref name="cvusr"/> His work was also included into English-, French-, German-, [[Russian language|Russian-]] and [[Serbian language|Serbian-language]] anthologies.<ref name="cvusr"/>
There are several controversial aspects to Gârbea's public notoriety, involving reactions against academic verdicts, and objecting to the close relationship between Gârbea and mainstream cultural forums such as the USR. The implications of positive appraisals by these venues were debated by literary critic [[Bogdan Creţu]], who argued that Nicolae Manolescu tended to overrate authors in his proximity, while being dismissive of Vişniec's contribution to drama (which Manolescu had claimed lacked originality).<ref name="bcesecul"/> Critic [[Dan C. Mihăilescu]] criticized in particular Manolescu's "caprices", suggesting that, in a 2008 synthesis of Romanian literary history, his older colleague had assigned Gârbea's entry undeserved space, more than to a better known novelist like [[Gib Mihăescu]].<ref name="dcmcronic">[[Dan C. Mihăilescu]], "Cronicarul în cumpăna istoriei", in ''[[Idei în Dialog]]'', Nr. 1(52), January 2009</ref> Also according to Mihăilescu, Cărtărescu may have had his rival Gârbea in mind when reproaching Manolescu that he had insisted on writers who were not at all worthy of recognition.<ref name="dcmcronic"/> Nicolae Oprea saw Gârbea as apparently "uninhibited" in matters of literary discourse, but critically noted that the poet was also preoccupied, "to the point of obsession", with his own cultural imprint (citing as proof the fact that, in its original version, ''Creşterea iguanelor de casă'' features the English-language versions of five poems, translated by Gârbea's own hand).<ref name="notexte"/> A highly critical voice is that of Bianca Burţa-Cernat. She suggests that, in adopting all forms of writing, Gârbea displays "an implausible self-certainty".<ref name="bbcradem"/> She polemically connects the critical appreciation with his status as a "good colleague" and "devoted shadow" of other writers, noting that Gârbea's notoriety is ensured by a promotional system with "all the stakes" and "all the pulleys", as well as by "the argument of prolificity", but that these attributes also surpass his actual value.<ref name="bbcradem"/>
===Plays=== Usually assigned by their author the name of "texts", in preference over "plays",<ref name="notexte"/><ref name="madrazb"/><ref name="ospotop"/> several among Gârbea's earliest works for the stage are Postmodern reworkings of classical motifs, fashioned into new statements about the limits of literature. His ''Pescăruşul din livada cu vişini'' is a personal take on [[Anton Chekhov]]'s ''[[The Cherry Orchard|Cherry Orchard]]'' and ''[[The Seagull|Seagull]]''. According to the author's own assessment, the text fits in with a Chekhovian homage trend among Romanian dramatists, also including [[Iosif Naghiu]]'s {{lang|ro|Armurierul Cehov}} ("Chekhov the Armorer") and Vişniec's ''La machine Tchekhov'' ("The Chekhov Machine").<ref>{{ro icon}} Horia Gârbea, [http://www.cuvantul.ro/articol/?artID=24&nr=320 "Pescăruşul din livada cu vişini"], in ''[[Cuvântul (literary magazine)|Cuvântul]]'', Nr. 320</ref> Soviany singles out the text as an answer to claims that parody is always inferior to its models, by identifying its original motifs in a new statement about theater itself: "[the play], which is without doubt ascribable to the formula of 'apocalyptic' theater, draws its substance from mixing intertextual parody with an [[Eschatology|eschatologic]] vision, suggesting the regression (of world and literature) into the primordial mud. Putting to use [...] the [[deluge myth]], the dramatist this time imagines an apocalypse of fiction (of the theater), during which the characters [...] are slowly being swallowed by the mud flows of subterranean waters, which could imply that literature (fiction) unavoidably secretes its own death, so that writing (being written) and dying end up being perfect synonyms."<ref name="ospotop"/> In this analogy between literature and death, Soviany argues, one finds "the most profound message of Horia Gârbea's theater".<ref name="ospotop"/> In ''Doamna Bovary sînt ceilalţi'', the theme and protagonists are borrowed from [[Gustave Flaubert]]'s [[Madame Bovary|1857 novel]], reused by the author to make a statement about drama itself<ref name="madrazb"/> and combined with elements from [[Jean-Paul Sartre]]'s ''[[No Exit]]''.<ref name="andespre"/> In addition to such themes, Mircea A. Diaconu sees Gârbea's reflection on the conflict between history and fiction as personified by the lead character in ''Stăpânul tăcerii'': the [[Egyptian pantheon|Egyptian god]] [[Thoth]], who bestows the gift of language on man, is depicted as "the prototype of traitors."<ref name="madrazb"/>
Published ten years after the [[Romanian Revolution of 1989|Romanian Revolution]], ''Decembrie, în direct'' recounts a changing of roles between torturer and victim, set to the background of political turmoil.<ref name="andespre"/><ref name="rcsecurit"/> In the first part, it introduces the two protagonists: a failed boxer turned interrogator for the main communist repressive structure, the [[Securitate]], who confronts his prisoner, a renegade [[nomenklatura]] member who has become a [[dissident]].<ref name="rcsecurit"/> What is supposed to be an ordeal for the latter turns into a revelation for the former: the dissident is successful in assuring his interrogator that communism is doomed, and both flee the prison to partake in the victorious Revolution. The second part sees the dissident transformed into an agent for the reformed [[Serviciul Român de Informaţii|Intelligence Service]], who displays no qualms about capturing, tormenting and finally killing his former associate.<ref name="rcsecurit"/> Historiographer and critic [[Ruxandra Cesereanu]] connects the outcome with a notoriously violent episode in Romania's communist history, the [[brainwashing]] experiment carried out by the Securitate in [[Piteşti prison]]: "The paradox and [[moral]]-antimoral of Horia Gârbea's play is that the victim [...] proves himself tougher, more of an executioner, than his torturer. This means that the lines between victim and executioner are blurred and that, ultimately, the reeducation experiment in Piteşti prison (1949-1952), when victims were forced into becoming torturers, has succeeded. The antimoral in Gârbea's play is, however, all the more tough as the victim here becomes a torturer without being made to do so."<ref name="rcsecurit"/> Cesereanu ranks it and [[Radu Macrinici]]'s ''T/Ţara mea'' (approx. "My Dead Weight/Country") among the post-1989 dramatic texts to have "brought up [...] the Securitate issue, in a trenchant and even revelatory manner".<ref name="rcsecurit"/> Gârbea's fellow playwright [[Alina Nelega]] notes that ''Decembrie, în direct'' is his first entirely original text for the stage, and rates it over intertextual texts from the same period.<ref name="andespre"/>
Published alongside ''Decembrie, în direct'', ''Capul lui Moţoc'' ("Moţoc's Head") reinterprets ''[[Alexandru Lăpuşneanu (novella)|Alexandru Lăpuşneanu]]'', a [[novella]] by the Romanian classic [[Costache Negruzzi]], which romanticizes events in [[Moldavia]]'s [[Romania in the Middle Ages|medieval history]]. Integrating further allusions to [[Folklore of Romania|Romanian folklore]] (the ''[[Meşterul Manole]]'' myth), Shakespeare and various others, it is also seen by Alina Nelega as a close rendition of Ion Luca Caragiale's style.<ref name="andespre"/> The protagonist, a treacherous Moldavian [[boyar]] by the name of Moţoc, uses a discourse rich in political imagery, and towards the end of the play reveals himself as an ''[[alter ego]]'' of [[Communism|communist]] theorist [[Karl Marx]].<ref name="andespre"/> Nelega is critical of the text, arguing that it "does not surpass the gratuitousness of petty pokes" and is "more [[burlesque]] than absurd", concluding: "I fear that Gârbea did not know how to end his play and quickly fabricated, ''[[deus ex machina]]'', the similitude of a profound sense where there was nothing."<ref name="andespre"/>
The three-character [[comedy]] and [[satire]] ''Cafeaua domnului Ministru'', seen by poet and literary chronicler [[Emil Mladin]] as one "of morals",<ref name="emdeparte">{{ro icon}} [[Emil Mladin]], [http://www.revistadrama.ro/drama1207/texte/laborator.htm "Laborator. Departe de lumea dezlănţuită"], in [http://www.revistadrama.ro/ ''Revista Drama''], Nr. 1-2/2007</ref> turns its attention to [[Politics of Romania|Romania's political scene]], showing the stormy encounter between a matron, a female secretary and a politician.<ref name="andespre"/><ref name="emdeparte"/> The dialogues are seen by Mladin as "a parody of the discourses with which just about any television station assassinates us",<ref name="emdeparte"/> and, Nelega writes, "the lampoon has precise targets".<ref name="andespre"/> The story pokes fun at the [[Social Democratic Party (Romania)|Social Democratic Party]] and [[Romanian Democratic Convention]] governments of the [[History of Romania since 1989|post-1989 period]], and, according to dramatist and theater critic Mihaela Michailov, was "adequate" in the context of [[Romanian legislative election, 2000|2000 elections]].<ref name="mmginditi"/> Michailov highlights the play's symbolism as illustrating "the stupidity of the political mechanism", whose sphere is turned into "a sort of [[no man's land]] where everything is possible."<ref name="mmginditi"/> According to Alex. Ştefănescu, productions of ''Cafeaua domnului Ministru'' receive as much applause as "a [[rock music]] recital."<ref name="asprea-pl"/> With ''Leonida XXI'', the author returned to intertextual reworkings, this time introducing his style to the works of Ion Luca Caragiale, ''[[Conu Leonida faţă cu reacţiunea]]'' and ''[[O scrisoare pierdută]]''.<ref name="ipalbulescu">{{ro icon}} Iulia Popovici, [http://www.ziua.net/display.php?data=2002-11-18&id=104926 "Mircea Albulescu: 'Aş vrea foarte mult ca cititorii, spectatorii, ascultătorii mei să vrea să nu mă piardă' "], in ''[[Ziua]]'', November 18, 2002</ref> The play was notably used as teaching material for student actors training at the [[Caragiale Academy of Theatrical Arts and Cinematography|Caragiale Academy]] under [[Mircea Albulescu]], who called it "extremely interesting".<ref name="ipalbulescu"/>
===From ''Căderea Bastiliei'' to ''Creşterea iguanelor de casă''=== With his debut novel ''Căderea Bastiliei'', Gârbea produces a satirical portrayal of his fellow Romanian writers, disguising their real names with [[anagram]]s or other [[word play]].<ref name="asprea-pl"/><ref name="pacarnav"/><ref name="cccaderea"/><ref name="egppachet"/><ref name="cmspumna">{{ro icon}} Cornelia Maria Savu, [http://www.revistacultura.ro/Cornelia_Maria_Savu/Pumnagiul,_Cri.../ "Pumnagiul, Criticessa şi Profetul"], in ''Cultura'', Nr. 82/2007</ref> Alex. Ştefănescu, who writes that such portrayals caused "great agitation in the literary world", cites the author's own mock-[[disclaimer]]: "The identification of some characters with real person constitutes an abuse of interpretation which the author intends to fight off with any legal means."<ref name="asprea-pl"/> Ştefănescu however cautions against reading ''Căderea Bastiliei'' purely as a ''[[roman à clef]]'', since the inspiration from "writers' deeds" is "capricious" and the resemblance with real persons "partial".<ref name="asprea-pl"/> A similar opinion was voiced by poet and journalist Cornelia Maria Savu, who compared the narrator to a puppeteer and further assessed: "Horia Gârbea does not hate his characters, does not love them, he understands them. And by understanding them, he offers them a few moments to evolve with no strings."<ref name="cmspumna"/> Reviewing the work from a stylistic point of view, Paul Aretzu analyzes the intrusion of "intertextual indulgences" throughout the work, identifying allusions to Ion Luca Caragiale, [[Franz Kafka]], [[Ioan Alexandru Brătescu-Voineşti]] and others, while also noting the presence of experimental methods echoing [[James Joyce]]'s ''[[Ulysses (novel)|Ulysses]]''.<ref name="pacarnav"/> Ştefănescu attributes such presences to parody, noting in passing the introduction of situations and even entire passages from Kafka's ''[[The Metamorphosis|Metamorphosis]]'' and [[Albert Camus]]' ''[[The Plague]]''.<ref name="asprea-pl"/>
The narrative delves into Bucharest's [[Bohemianism|bohemian]] environment, its heroes being vagrants, misfits or [[Alcoholism|alcoholics]] who lead [[Tragicomedy|tragicomic]] lifestyles.<ref name="pacarnav"/> The plot, deemed "to die for" by Galaicu-Păun,<ref name="egppachet"/> notably shows writer and former inmate Aldu Rădulescu seducing literary chronicler Alteea Fleciu, as revenge for a negative review of his work.<ref name="asprea-pl"/><ref name="egppachet"/> In Paul Aretzu's view, the manner in which such developments are presented constitutes "a continuous demonstration of brilliant intelligence and spectacular linguistic imagination."<ref name="pacarnav"/> He commends a chapter of the book, which discusses how groups of people differentiated by their respective [[drinking culture]]s, for being "a sort of poem dedicated to the kinds of drink and drunks in a small alcoholic town", while noting that a similar section, dedicated to the attitudes of writers when faced with fatal diseases, "creates, with the means of the [[grotesque]], a ''[[sui generis]]'' mythology of the writers' caste".<ref name="pacarnav"/> The latter episode is praised by Ştefănescu for its "irresistible" [[black humor]] and its "devilish verve".<ref name="asprea-pl"/> The same commentator states: "The novelist has a joy of writing that transmits itself to the reader. After you finish reading this novel about the ugliness of (literary) life [...], you feel, paradoxically, the joy of living, of communicating, of partaking in the captivating spectacle of being."<ref name="asprea-pl"/> In Artezu's account, those parts of ''Căderea Bastiliei'' in which Gârbea discusses the annual competition for literary prizes offer evidence both a "captivating" humorous focus on everyday occurrences and an "innocent [[Cynicism (contemporary)|cynicism]], characteristic for the author".<ref name="pacarnav"/> He argues: "With all the signs of his emotional involvement [...], the author also exercises, through correlations [and] quotes, the function of [[depersonalization]], of estrangement, of laughing at one's misfortunes, of projecting oneself into clichés, [...] of surrogate existence."<ref name="pacarnav"/> Literary reviewer [[Cosmin Ciotloş]] issues a more reserved verdict on the text: in his view, the episodes of ''Căderea Bastiliei'' are primarily "charades", whose main quality is being "droll".<ref name="cccaderea"/>
Overall, Horia Gârbea's contribution to short fiction is described by Alex. Ştefănescu as "ingenious" and "endearing".<ref name="asprea-pl"/> The [[political fiction]] of {{lang|ro|Enigme în oraşul nostru}} is described by Boerescu as "a multitude of sub-worlds" structured around "framework situations", moving between the "petty politics of the day" (targeting the Social Democratic Party) and ironic [[parable]]s or [[dystopia]]s.<ref name="dsbpostm"/> Boerescu writes: "The author cannot refrain from endlessly staging acts and short plays or inserting lines with an obvious dramatic hue".<ref name="dsbpostm"/> The same commentator identifies in the stories several allusions, homages or intertextual borrowings, from the "[[Semiotics|semiotic]] games" of [[Umberto Eco]] to a "landscape of luxuriant vegetation" characteristic for the [[Latin American Boom]] writers.<ref name="dsbpostm"/> This symbolism is coupled with allusions to Romanian literary life: the final story in the collection, ''Motanii din bibliotecă'' ("The Tomcats in the Study Hall"), speculates about the future of Gârbea's generation, and depicts [[bibliophile]]s keeping pets named after the leading literary critics of the 1980s and '90s.<ref name="dsbpostm"/>
Among his poetry collections, ''Creşterea iguanelor de casă'' drew attention for transferring the intertextual and parodic conventions into a lyrical format, mostly [[free verse]]. According to Ştefănescu, it and his other poetry collections are "better than those by most contemporary authors who emphatically recommend themselves as poets."<ref name="asprea-pl"/> Nicolae Oprea noted in particular the reworking of a motif borrowed from [[Sibiu Literary Circle|Sibiu Circle]] poet [[Ştefan Augustin Doinaş]] and his ''[[Mistreţul cu colţi de argint]]'': the "prince from the [[Levant]]", whom Gârbea transfers into the destitute world of garbage collectors.<ref name="notexte"/> Part of it reads: {{Verse translation| {{lang|ro|dimineaţa pe la ora patru pe nemâncate îi aduna prinţul-poet pe gunoieri nu mai făcea apelul erau toţi şi îi întreba bă voi ziceţi că omu-i o lumină da moşule ziceau aia este bine scrâşnea prinţul-poet mai mult prinţ vai de poezia lui bine marş la treabă şi plecau să măture ce să facă}}<ref name="notexte"/> | morning round four on an empty stomach the prince-poet would gather the garbage men he wouldn't call them out they were all there and would ask them you people say that man is a light yes dude they said that's what man is fine gnashed the prince-poet or rather just prince his sorry poetry fine shoo back to work and they started sweeping what else could they do}}
Oprea also highlighted ironic and dismissive borrowings from Romania's [[national poet]] [[Mihai Eminescu]], and from [[Poet Laureate|poets laureate]] such as [[Octavian Goga]] and [[Vasile Alecsandri]], as well as an actual lineage from the black humor of 1930s Surrealists.<ref name="notexte"/> He sees a direct link between Gârbea and the Romanian Surrealist group's [[Gellu Naum]], and beyond, to the "existential" [[absurdism]] of Ionesco and Kafka.<ref name="notexte"/> Also according to Oprea, such texts "are raised as collages of everyday images and bookish suggestions, well tied to each other, to the point where their articulation into colloquial speech puts to use the technique of reabsorbing the dramatic element and the narrative nucleus of [[ballad]]esque nature into the sphere of pure [[lyricism]]."<ref name="notexte"/>
===''Crime la Elsinore'' and ''Trecute vieţi de fanţi şi de birlici''=== ''Crime la Elsinore'' is a return to prose satire, in this case directed at the theatrical environment. The setting is a fictional theater in provincial [[Călăraşi]], deriving its name from the [[Getae|Getic]] ruler [[Dromichaetes]], and the protagonists, Cosmin Ciotloş notes, are composite portrayals rather than the "masked" characters of ''Căderea Bastiliei''.<ref name="cccaderea"/> He argues: "Whichever way you look at it, set free from the contextual interpretations exercised in reading [[tabloid (newspaper format)|tabloid]]s, the novel stands only to gain."<ref name="cccaderea"/> The narrative focus is on the [[kitsch]]y ambition of a failed theater manager, Cosma, who proceeds to conflate all the violent moments of [[Shakespearean tragedy]] into a single show of regular proportions.<ref name="bbcradem"/><ref name="cccaderea"/> The project is increasingly confused, and the text used by Cosma mixes Shakespeare's lines with quotes from [[Pierre Beaumarchais]], [[Euripides]] and [[Molière]], while adopting the format of a [[detective novel]].<ref name="bbcradem"/>
Ciotloş reproached ''Crime la Elsinore'' for lack of subtlety, in the presence of a "not exactly indispensable" [[glossary]] of terms which was published with the book.<ref name="cccaderea"/> Although he acknowledges that the writing is "amusing", he also contends that it is "impossible to extend [[Sociology|sociologically]] or connect to some reality", being isolated "in its own world", and displaying "compositional precariousness."<ref name="cccaderea"/> He concludes: "A book perfect in its own way, but far from perfection in ours."<ref name="cccaderea"/> A similar overview is provided by Burţa-Cernat, who contends that, in taking sides and explaining his intentions, the author adopts "the manner of an untalented journalist", with "see-through" results.<ref name="bbcradem"/> She also believes that Gârbea's chief comedic resource is "the cheap [[anecdote]] with a trite climax", which she compares with those published by the communist-era magazine ''[[Urzica (magazine)|Urzica]]''.<ref name="bbcradem"/> Additionally, Burţa-Cernat comments on the irony of Cosma's reliance on intertextuality, which she finds similar to Gârbea's own work for the stage.<ref name="bbcradem"/> Critic [[Andrei Terian]] noted that he disliked almost all the book, because of its author's tendency to humiliate his characters "before us readers are in the least familiarized with them."<ref name="atfratele"/>
In ''Trecute vieţi de fanţi şi de birlici'', Gârbea revisits the main themes of Romanian literature, looking into the biographies of various fictional characters, their lifestyles, personal preferences and social positioning. He himself defined the overview as "a sort of collection of essays on the edge of literary history."<ref name="abprofesia"/> One of its chapters compares the [[tabletop game]]s entertaining such figures, from the [[contract bridge]] parties in [[Camil Petrescu]]'s books and the antiquated [[card game]]s in Mateiu Caragiale's ''[[Craii de Curtea-Veche]]'' to the cruder [[craps]] and [[gambling]] preferred by thieves in [[Eugen Barbu]]'s novels.<ref name="emscriitori"/> Other sections discuss the attitudes toward love in such diverse places as [[Marin Sorescu]]'s neorealist prose and the [[Fantasy literature|fantasy]] short stories of [[Mircea Eliade]].<ref name="emscriitori"/> Likewise, the avatars of violence are depicted between Ion Luca Caragiale's satire ''[[D-ale carnavalului]]'', where people threaten to poison each other with [[sulfuric acid]], [[Anton Bacalbaşa]]'s depictions of officers disciplining their subordinates with the use of belts, and [[Marin Preda]]'s ''[[Moromeţii]]'', where peasants beat each other with clubs.<ref name="emscriitori"/> Another part of the book deals with the incidence of failure among intellectual protagonists, and leads Gârbea to conclude that, with the exception of [[Mihail Sebastian]]'s ''[[Accidentul]]'', Romanian narratives generally show their intellectual protagonists incapable of finding their way in life.<ref name="sdpitor"/> According to [[Daniel Cristea-Enache]], Gârbea generally and willingly limited the scope of his investigation to canonical and urbane [[literary realism]], avoiding [[Allegory|allegorical]] styles such as [[Onirism]]: "the author is not interested in symbolic codification, in the [[refraction]] of the characters and their fictional world; but, quite the contrary, in the points and lines at which literature intersects with social life."<ref name="dc-ejoc"/>
In his review of the volume, Emil Mladin deemed it "wonderful" and "an extremely welcome project", noting: "''Trecute vieţi de fanţi şi de birlici'' represents a link which the reader needed in his relationship with the characters of stories relevant both at the time of their writing and today."<ref name="emscriitori"/> According to literary critic Silvia Dumitrache, the book creates "new paths in interpretation [...] even when starting from literary locations that are often threatened with turning into clichés."<ref name="sdpitor"/> She concludes "Through the playful note he impresses on the book, Horia Gârbea proves that his main intention does not reside in the willingness to impose a new [[Hermeneutics|hermeneutic]] grid on Romanian literature, but in the attempt to demonstrate that the resources of literature can never, ever, be entirely exhausted."<ref name="sdpitor"/> Cristea-Enache sees in ''Trecute vieţi de fanţi şi de birlici'' "a book as interesting as it is enjoyable [...]. A holiday read, one could say, had this sytagm not been bastardized, in our country, by so many printed works (volumes and journals alike) that offend the reader's intellect."<ref name="dc-ejoc"/>
Outside the critical reevaluation of local literature, Gârbea's work includes short humorous essays about various topics in post-1989 society and modern [[Culture of Romania|Romanian culture]]. One such chapter is built around the polemic between Gârbea and writer [[Gheorghe Grigurcu]], over the issue of what it means for a working artist to be treated unjustly or be privileged.<ref name="dc-ejoc"/> Another fragment documents and ridicules the impact of [[instant messaging]] on the [[Romanian lexis]], with the rapid spread of abbreviations such as ''sal'' (for ''salut'', "hello"), ''vb'' (''vorbim'', "we'll talk") and ''ms'' (''mersi'', "thanks").<ref name="sdpitor"/> Gârbea also pokes fun at the [[babytalk]]-based [[jargon]] of parenting magazines, and contrasts its apparent artificiality with the awe he records having personally experienced after the birth of his son Tudor.<ref name="dc-ejoc"/> It reads: "[He] does not inspire in me the image of fragility and fondness, but the force of an entity which benefits from the advantage of The Unknown. When I call him using his human name, he smiles down on me, with devastating irony, so that I may grasp my complete lack of fantasizing ability. No matter what will happen in the future, these winter days [...] shall always remain for me under the sign of having met, for the first time in life, an inexplicable creature."<ref name="dc-ejoc"/>
===Other works=== ''Fratele mai deştept al lui Kalaşnikov'', which comprises several stories, received mixed reviews. According to Andrei Terian, the main one, ''Articolul 96'' ("Article 96"), which is about a lecherous politician dating an [[Anorexia nervosa|anorexic]] model, has the same defects as ''Crime...''.<ref name="atfratele"/> In contrast, Terian notes, Gârbea shows his "sure hand" in other pieces, where he parodies ''Povestea unui om leneş'' ("The Story of a Lazy Man") by 19th century Romanian classic [[Ion Creangă]], or where he pokes fun at the 14th century [[Battle of Rovine]], as well as the [[Absurdism|absurdist]] ''Întoarcerea tatei din război. Subiecte'' ("Father's Return from War. Subjects"), where the same narrative cliché is explored from several conflicting perspectives.<ref name="atfratele"/> According to Terian, the volume as a whole displays influences from poet and satirist [[Tudor Arghezi]], as well as borrowings from fellow parodist [[Ioan Groşan]].<ref name="atfratele"/>
''Azerbaijan - The Living Flame'' details Gârbea's trip and offers additional insight into the [[Nagorno-Karabakh War]] and other conflicts between [[Azerbaijani people]] and [[Armenians]]. It features his poems about [[Shusha]] city, the [[Khojaly Massacre]] and the [[Guba mass grave]].<ref name="trendflame"/> The texts received criticism from the [[Armenians in Romania|Armenian Romanian]] community's ''Ararat'' journal: it specifically called "disinformation" the fragments which refer to [[Christianity in Azerbaijan|Azerbaijan's Christian past]], and expressed concern over Gârbea's claim that [[Heydar Aliyev]] was "a civilizing providential hero".<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.araratonline.com/2010/03/03/despre-un-neverosimil-%E2%80%9Efoc-viu%E2%80%9C/ "Despre un neverosimil 'foc viu' "], in ''Ararat'', March 3, 2010</ref>
